I put my drone down and let it rest, after trying this python script

column2: from dronekit import connect, VehicleMode, LocationGlobalRelative

column3: print(""Waiting for drone to be armable..."")
# Break and return from function just below target altitude.

column1: Which is basically taken from their tutorials, i get the error ""CRITICAL:autopilot:PreArm: EKF2 still initialising"" and cannot arm. When i try arming using an rc connection it works fine, as well as when usb connected to qgroundcontrol. Any suggestions?
I'm using a pixhawk connected via serial port to rasp pi. My pixhawk is connected only to the motors and pi. No gps. I'd post this on the ardupilot forums but i only get this issue with dronekit.",,

But when I use Dronekit to upload a mission file, it comes back looking very strange.
Here's the (simplified) code I use to upload:
# Load a mission from a file into a list. The mission definition is in the Waypoint file
# This function is used by upload_mission().
raise Exception('File is not supported WP version')
cmd = Command(0, 0, 0, ln_frame, ln_command, ln_currentwp, ln_autocontinue, ln_param1, ln_param2,
I've read about rounding issues in the official dronekit documentation: https://dronekit-python.readthedocs.io/en/latest/examples/mission_import_export.html

However, I've checked right up to the final upload, and there don't seem to be any rounding issues. So unless its something deep in the pymavlink library or on the pixhawk itself (which I doubt because uploading and downloading via mission planner does not cause this issue), I don't think this is the issue.

in the wiki they say that you should open an issue before trying to use channel override.

We are a students group developing a drone that should pick objects up. To center on the objects we're setting the vehicle-velocity setting in GUIDED-Mode with dronekit. However, the guided-mode doesn't seem to be suitable for landing, as the motors don't turn off automaticly (we tried it once and the copter flipped and crashed, but that was like 6 months ago).

That's why we need to use the landing-mode at some point (the copter should center all the way till right before the motors disarm).  However, the landing mode doesn't support the send vehicle-velocity settings, the only option nowadays is to use the channel-override method.

Maybe is there an option we missed to check if the drone has already landed, so that we can use guided-mode? (like in the fc-software). As now I don't see a better way as to use channel-override ([specification for landing mode](https://ardupilot.org/copter/docs/land-mode.html) )

,,

24,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/966,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/966/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/966/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/966/events,https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/966,477497258,MDU6SXNzdWU0Nzc0OTcyNTg=,966,Manual Override ,{'login': 'priyankamadhavan', 'id': 46007515, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjQ2MDA3NTE1', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars3.githubusercontent.com/u/46007515?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/priyankamadhavan', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/priyankamadhavan', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/priyankamadhavan/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/priyankamadhavan/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/priyankamadhavan/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/priyankamadhavan/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/priyankamadhavan/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/priyankamadhavan/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/priyankamadhavan/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/priyankamadhavan/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/priyankamadhavan/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}",[],closed,False,,[],,2,2019-08-06 17:11:23+00:00,2019-08-09 14:39:49+00:00,2019-08-09 14:39:49+00:00,NONE,,"I am working on a project where we are trying to implement communications between 2 drones. The basic structure is: Drone1 sends a command to Drone2 (through UDP and Python Socket) to first arm, then takeoff, and fly to up 5 meters. Drone2 then sends a message to Drone1 to fly up 5 meters. When testing this, the altitude sensors on our drones can be iffy, which results in them flying higher than intended, and after about 30 seconds they end up crashing down.

We want to create a manual takeover command so we can use our RC Remotes to pilot the drones if something like this were to happen again. It seems like the only way to do this is with channel overrides, which is strongly advised against in the documentation. We are able to run RC commands on the drones, but when running our message code, it seems like the RC is disabled.

x, y, z,  # x, y, z positions
0, 0, 0,  # x, y, z velocity in m/s
0, 0)  # yaw, yaw_rate (not supported yet, ignored in GCS_Mavlink)
According to my understanding of the code, the drone should arm and take off to 5 meters which it does pretty well.
The first home location printed is ```LocationGlobal:lat=-35.3632609,lon=149.1652299,alt=0.584```
After this, drone moves forward for 5 meters maintaining the altitude at 5 meters (expected too)  and new home location is updated(till here it works pretty much well).
Now, to my understanding since new home location has been updated, then giving
```cmdBodyPosition(0, 0, 0)``` command should not let drone move from its position. But to the surprise, it maintains its altitude but goes back to its original latitude position.
I have observed that drone moves relative to the Z location when giving ```cmdBodyPosition``` command when home location is updated. But X and Y are relative to the first home location.

68,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/877,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/877/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/877/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/877/events,https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/877,381970684,MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0MjMxNzk0OTUy,877,Add commands and tests for sensor calibration,"{'login': 'pietrodn', 'id': 5058646, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjUwNTg2NDY=', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars3.githubusercontent.com/u/5058646?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/pietrodn', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}",[],closed,False,,[],,13,2018-11-18 15:28:47+00:00,2018-12-31 18:22:35+00:00,2018-12-31 10:38:49+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"When handling a drone fleet, it is useful to calibrate the drones from DroneKit's API without resorting to QGroundControl, which requires manual operation.
This is especially true for the calibrations which don't require any manual intervention (gyro, barometer, board level), since they can be carried out on the entire fleet in parallel.
In this PR, I added the support for the calibration of:
To test the commands, I developed a generic function able to listen to the `COMMAND_ACK` messages and to assert that a specific command has been ACKed.
The accelerometer calibrations are expected to return the `MAV_RESULT_FAILED` status, since in the SITL there's nobody moving the drone.
Still, it's useful to check the ACK status to make sure that the autopilot does not respond with an ""unsupported"" or ""denied"" status.

The magnetometer calibration is expected to return the `MAV_RESULT_UNSUPPORTED` status in the tests because the `MAV_CMD_DO_START_MAG_CAL` is not supported in APM Copter 3.3 (the current version of the SITL), however it is supported in the latest ArduPilot master.

PX4, on the other hand, handles the magnetometer calibration using the standard `MAV_CMD_PREFLIGHT_CALIBRATION` message, so I had to handle the two cases in `Vehicle.calibrate_magnetometer()`.",,"{'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/pulls/877', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/877', 'diff_url': 'https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/877.diff', 'patch_url': 'https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/877.patch'}"

72,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/871,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/871/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/871/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/871/events,https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/871,377134686,MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0MjI4MTY1NTk5,871,Logging: use builtin logging module for library and autopilot output,"{'login': 'pietrodn', 'id': 5058646, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjUwNTg2NDY=', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars3.githubusercontent.com/u/5058646?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/pietrodn', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}",[],closed,False,,[],,8,2018-11-04 09:11:38+00:00,2018-11-12 07:13:21+00:00,2018-11-11 22:57:50+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"## Current situation
DroneKit does not play well in the logging department when it's used as a library.
Indeed, the user has no way to configure DroneKit's logging apart from monkey-patching (#862).

The logging of MAVLink `STATUSTEXT` messages can be configured by providing a `status_printer` function to `connect()`; however, while the `STATUSTEXT` message [provides](https://mavlink.io/en/messages/common.html#STATUSTEXT) the severity level ([`MAV_SEVERITY` enum](https://mavlink.io/en/messages/common.html#MAV_SEVERITY)) in a field, DroneKit ignores it and prints all the messages from the autopilot with the same severity.
Also, when an exception is encountered in an attribute or message handler, the stack trace does not get printed, making debugging more difficult.

This PR tries to improve the situation by replacing all the uses of `errprinter()` and `print()` with the built-in Python [`logging`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/logging.html) module facilities.
The stack trace is printed (`exc_info=True`) in case of ""unexpected"" exceptions coming from user's code.

`STATUSTEXT` messages are logged by a separate logger to make it clear which messages are coming from the autopilot and which others are emitted from the DroneKit library; the two loggers may be configured independently.
The `STATUSTEXT` messages are printed with the correct logging level specified by the autopilot: filtering by severity is now possible.
With the proposed changes, the library user would be able to format, filter, redirect and suppress DroneKit's and the autopilot's log messages at his/her pleasure.

A nice side effect of this change is that the tests now run completely silent, because nose [captures](https://nose.readthedocs.io/en/latest/plugins/logcapture.html) all the log messages and prints them only in case of error.
To force the printing of log messages in test output, one can do:

74,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/869,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/869/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/869/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/869/events,https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/869,376316819,MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0MjI3NTYwMDk1,869,mavlink.py: specific exception handling for MAVError,"{'login': 'pietrodn', 'id': 5058646, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjUwNTg2NDY=', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars3.githubusercontent.com/u/5058646?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/pietrodn', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}",[],closed,False,,[],,2,2018-11-01 09:31:01+00:00,2018-11-01 10:25:08+00:00,2018-11-01 09:43:27+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"In `mavlink.py`, in `mavlink_thread_in`, specifically catch and ignore `MAVError` (the sporadic messages ""invalid MAVLink prefix..."" are all MAVErrors), avoiding to swallow legitimate exceptions with a broad `except` clause.

This patch should make it easier to debug DroneKit + pymavlink as library code for developers: it's very hard to diagnose problems if the program silently fails.",,"{'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/pulls/869', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/869', 'diff_url': 'https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/869.diff', 'patch_url': 'https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/869.patch'}"

It turns out that virtualenv is already bundled in the Docker images: there's no need to install it.",,"{'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/pulls/867', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/867', 'diff_url': 'https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/867.diff', 'patch_url': 'https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/867.patch'}"

77,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/866,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/866/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/866/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/866/events,https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/866,375716545,MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0MjI3MDk5NzY0,866,"Performance improvements (comparisons with None, True, False)","{'login': 'pietrodn', 'id': 5058646, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjUwNTg2NDY=', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars3.githubusercontent.com/u/5058646?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/pietrodn', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}",[],closed,False,,[],,5,2018-10-30 22:16:22+00:00,2018-10-31 23:07:06+00:00,2018-10-31 23:06:21+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"While profiling my DroneKit-based application with yappi, I noticed that the [`MAVLink_message.__eq__()`](https://github.com/ArduPilot/pymavlink/blob/eaa2ab77e9490f0427d86a2401ab61c99b6bca2b/generator/mavgen_python.py#L165) method was called more than 1.9 million times over a few minutes.
It was the function called with the greatest frequency in the whole application, and consumed a lot of CPU time.

I inspected the call stack using QCacheGrind and found out that all of these calls were comparisons of a MAVLink message object with `None`. All of them can be avoided by using the idiomatic constructs `is None` / `is not None`.
Some of these calls (~13k) were from pymavlink: these [are already gone](https://github.com/ArduPilot/pymavlink/pull/235).

All the other calls are coming from DroneKit, specifically from [this line of code](https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/blob/4e392d603818ff29eadf6518122c6418d6c67f95/dronekit/__init__.py#L1285) inside a loop listener (a function executed once every few incoming MAVLink message):
# list containing 1 item for each parameter of the autopilot:
#Â each can be None (param not loaded) or a PARAM_VALUE message object
# for each non-None element in self._params_set
if None not in self._params_set and not self._params_loaded:
That code is expensive. The current version of PX4 has more than 500 parameters: even after all the parameters are loaded, on every message loop, DroneKit calls `MAVLink_message.__eq__()` 500+ times!
# Exploit short-circuiting of the and operator (check the boolean first)
# so that, if self._params_loaded == True, the array does not get checked;
# replace the expensive `__eq__()` call with a fast, idiomatic
if not self._params_loaded and all(x is not None for x in self._params_set):

I went ahead and fixed all the comparisons with `None`, `True`,  `False`, and replaced a double lookup in a dictionary with a `.get()` call.",,"{'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/pulls/866', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/866', 'diff_url': 'https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/866.diff', 'patch_url': 'https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/866.patch'}"

78,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/865,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/865/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/865/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/865/events,https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/865,374774493,MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0MjI2MzgxMDk0,865,pymavlink: Python 3 compatibility fix,"{'login': 'pietrodn', 'id': 5058646, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjUwNTg2NDY=', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars3.githubusercontent.com/u/5058646?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/pietrodn', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}",[],closed,False,,[],,11,2018-10-28 16:56:50+00:00,2018-11-15 05:41:24+00:00,2018-11-15 00:48:48+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"In the last weeks, pymavlink changed the way it handles strings and bytes in Python 3.

In particular, the `param_request_read_send()` function now accepts the parameter name only as bytes and not as string (references: [1](https://github.com/ArduPilot/pymavlink/commit/c16da2f26b2d0f19d692e870bbe589e7a39bb6b1), [2](https://github.com/ArduPilot/pymavlink/commit/5e97b20eeb255a8c956fce9366e71207f00e8484)).
This breaks Python 3 compatibility for DroneKit in some cases, namely when the line of code affected by this PR gets called in the Vehicle initialization phase (initial download of parameters).
I noticed this behaviour in the SITL tests, running on Python 3.7:
* `SITL_SPEEDUP=10 nosetests`: everything is OK, because that line of code never gets called
* `nosetests`: each test gets stuck at the ""Calibrating barometer"" phase, and times out

With this fix, the tests run correctly under Python 3 in both cases.",,"{'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/pulls/865', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/865', 'diff_url': 'https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/865.diff', 'patch_url': 'https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/865.patch'}"

79,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/864,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/864/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/864/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/864/events,https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/864,374727383,MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0MjI2MzQ5NDA4,864,mavlink.py: efficient I/O waiting with select(),"{'login': 'pietrodn', 'id': 5058646, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjUwNTg2NDY=', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars3.githubusercontent.com/u/5058646?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/pietrodn', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}",[],closed,False,,[],,7,2018-10-28 07:47:11+00:00,2018-10-31 23:08:24+00:00,2018-10-31 20:26:21+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"pymavlink uses non-blocking [sockets](https://github.com/ArduPilot/pymavlink/blob/master/mavutil.py#L926) and [serial ports](https://github.com/ArduPilot/pymavlink/blob/master/mavutil.py#L824): polling for data in a while loop with a `sleep(0.05)` is inefficient and leads to increased latency for incoming MAVLink messages (issue #863).
But, if the `sleep` call is blindly removed, then the CPU usage rises to 100% (busy-looping)!

The [`select()`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/select.html#select.select) system call, [exposed in the pymavlink API](https://github.com/ArduPilot/pymavlink/blob/master/mavutil.py#L209), puts the `mavlink_thread_in` thread to sleep for just the right amount of time and wakes it up when fresh data is ready to be processed.

If `select()` is used, the returned message may never be `None`, so the loop listeners would never get called. This is also fixed by ensuring that the loop listeners are called at least every 0.5 s.",,"{'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/pulls/864', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/864', 'diff_url': 'https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/864.diff', 'patch_url': 'https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/864.patch'}"

80,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/863,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/863/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/863/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/863/events,https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/863,374633164,MDU6SXNzdWUzNzQ2MzMxNjQ=,863,High latency in MAVLink message receiving,"{'login': 'pietrodn', 'id': 5058646, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjUwNTg2NDY=', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars3.githubusercontent.com/u/5058646?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/pietrodn', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}",[],closed,False,,[],,16,2018-10-27 10:58:45+00:00,2020-06-03 21:29:31+00:00,2018-10-31 23:04:19+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"I wrote a simple script to measure the MAVLink message latency (round-trip time) by exploiting the `TIMESYNC` protocol as implemented in PX4.
The protocol works like this: in the client application you send a `TIMESYNC` message to the autopilot, with:
* `ts1` set to the locally generated timestamp.
The firmware responds ([source code](https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/6f204c491335af88dcf1c13484e3d98f82868296/src/modules/mavlink/mavlink_timesync.cpp#L67)) with another `TIMESYNC`, having:
* the same `ts1` field (the timestamp of the original message);
* the autopilot's timestamp in the `tc1` field.

By observing the difference between the timestamp of arrival of the second message and its `ts1` field, you can effectively measure the round-trip time of the message and estimate the link latency (e.g. by assuming latency = RTT / 2).
You can also estimate the offset between the client and the autopilot's clocks using the `tc1` field, but I'm not interested in this right now.
I did the following experiment: send a `TIMESYNC` to the autopilot every 10 ms for 100 times, and measure the round-trip times from the answers.
I'm using the PX4 SITL simulator, so I'm communicating with the autopilot through UDP on the same host (ideal conditions, no packet loss).
I noticed a strange pattern in the measured latencies (**orange line** in the graph).
In the graph we can observe groups of 4-5 messages with strictly decreasing latencies, starting from 25 ms  down to about 5 ms or less.
I also observed the autopilot-generated timestamps (`tc1` field) and noticed that they were very regular (there were about 10 ms between them, always).
So, this must be a problem on the receiving side of the client.

The cause of the problem is [this line of code](https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/blob/5d2614f79092cc3ea03062a084579eb16577cd22/dronekit/mavlink.py#L207): `time.sleep(0.05)` in the `mavlink_thread_in` function.
That `sleep()` makes DroneKit wait 50 ms if no messages are found in the buffer; it matches the 25 ms delay shown in the graph (I'm plotting RTT / 2 as a latency estimate).
By removing the sleep, I get dramatically lower latencies (less than 1 ms on average): they are shown on the **blue line** in the above graph.
Why is that sleep there? Is it possible to remove it?
I'd like to do so to obtain a reliable estimate  of the link latency on the autopilot side.",,
Is there a way to mute console log outputs?

82,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/861,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/861/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/861/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/861/events,https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/861,372191199,MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0MjI0NDYyNzgz,861,Update pymavlink for Python 3 support,"{'login': 'pietrodn', 'id': 5058646, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjUwNTg2NDY=', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars3.githubusercontent.com/u/5058646?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/pietrodn', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}",[],closed,False,,[],,1,2018-10-20 09:07:17+00:00,2018-10-23 16:04:51+00:00,2018-10-21 22:24:53+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"pymavlink has been fixed ([1](https://github.com/ArduPilot/pymavlink/commit/5e97b20eeb255a8c956fce9366e71207f00e8484), [2](https://github.com/ArduPilot/pymavlink/commit/4d9c2754c64a7d02fa86b0043335269859e9028a), [3](https://github.com/ArduPilot/pymavlink/commit/4026f1df0f2bfd0925e307a34af7eaa348e0597d)) to correctly handle strings in both Python 2 and Python 3.
This means that with the latest pymavlink release, the SITL tests are finally passing for Python 3 also.

This PR bumps the pymavlink dependency to the latest stable version and re-enables the CircleCI Python 3 tests.",,"{'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/pulls/861', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/861', 'diff_url': 'https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/861.diff', 'patch_url': 'https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/861.patch'}"

MAV> Waiting for heartbeat from tcp:127.0.0.1:5760

Is this normal that it takes more than 15 seconds? Can this be improved?

machine (udp:127.0.0.1:14550) and also tried to directly connect dronekit
via the Serial/USB port to the PIXHAWK.
Mavproxy on the other hand needs less than 2 seconds.
(I did try various setting with wait_ready etc but no success)

I tested it on a Pixfalcon running PX4 and it works as expected.

The SITL doesn't support a real ""reboot"", but it still ACKs the command to the client. I added a test for that.",,"{'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/pulls/811', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/811', 'diff_url': 'https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/811.diff', 'patch_url': 'https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/811.patch'}"

8,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/810,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/810/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/810/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/810/events,https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/810,309057542,MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0MTc3ODA3NDMy,810,Upgrade CircleCI configuration to version 2.0,"{'login': 'pietrodn', 'id': 5058646, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjUwNTg2NDY=', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars3.githubusercontent.com/u/5058646?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/pietrodn', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}",[],closed,False,,[],,10,2018-03-27 17:12:43+00:00,2018-04-11 22:26:52+00:00,2018-04-11 19:14:30+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"This PR introduces CircleCI 2.0 support while deprecating CircleCI 1.0.
The reasons for this change are the following:
- [CircleCI 1.0 will reach End Of Life on August 31, 2018](https://circleci.com/blog/sunsetting-1-0/)
- Clearer environment definition thanks to Docker images
- Parallel Python 2 and Python 3 builds thanks to [workflows](https://circleci.com/docs/2.0/workflows/)
Currently this configuration [builds successfully](https://circleci.com/gh/pietrodn/dronekit-python/tree/circle2) using Python 2 on my CircleCI account.
The Python 3 build fails in the testing phase, [as expected](https://github.com/ArduPilot/pymavlink/pull/141).

I don't have the SSH keys for deployment so I cannot check if the deploy step is executed correctly. However, I [checked](https://circleci.com/gh/pietrodn/dronekit-python/21) that it attempts the deploy only on the correct branch specified by the filter.

Gitter notifications are working, as before.",,"{'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/pulls/810', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/810', 'diff_url': 'https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/810.diff', 'patch_url': 'https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/810.patch'}"

21,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/788,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/788/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/788/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/788/events,https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/788,290550555,MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0MTY0MzY5NDEy,788,Fixes and improvements for two SITL tests,"{'login': 'pietrodn', 'id': 5058646, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjUwNTg2NDY=', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars3.githubusercontent.com/u/5058646?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/pietrodn', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/pietrodn/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}",[],closed,False,,[],,1,2018-01-22 17:31:39+00:00,2018-01-23 05:46:01+00:00,2018-01-23 05:37:17+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"Sometimes the SITL tests in `test_mavlink.py` fail because the vehicles are not ready.
We can avoid this by adding `wait_ready=True` to the `Vehicle.connect()` call and obtain more reliable result.
Also, a timeout condition would never activate because a counter was not decreased when it should have to.
In `test_parameters.py`, I added parentheses to make the assignment more legible.

This pull request contains the non-Python3-compatibility fixes from #784.",,"{'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/pulls/788', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/788', 'diff_url': 'https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/788.diff', 'patch_url': 'https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/788.patch'}"

22,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/787,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/787/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/787/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/787/events,https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/787,290210409,MDU6SXNzdWUyOTAyMTA0MDk=,787,Running the scripts thru Mavproxy,"{'login': 'vincentwen1995', 'id': 29601049, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjI5NjAxMDQ5', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars0.githubusercontent.com/u/29601049?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/vincentwen1995', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/vincentwen1995', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/vincentwen1995/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/vincentwen1995/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/vincentwen1995/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/vincentwen1995/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/vincentwen1995/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/vincentwen1995/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/vincentwen1995/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/vincentwen1995/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/vincentwen1995/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}",[],closed,False,,[],,1,2018-01-20 17:56:36+00:00,2018-02-19 01:03:15+00:00,2018-02-19 01:03:15+00:00,NONE,,"Hi, I have a question about the compatibility of dronekit-python 2.0 with Mavproxy.

In our project, the pixhawk flight controller is used with a odroid-c2 companion computer. The connection between the pixhawk and the odroid is set up thru serial and between the ground station(PC) and the odroid is set up thru telemetry. The overall connection interface we are using is Mavproxy.
So while the drone is in the air, we don't have access to the shell of the odroid, and, therefore, could not simply run the python script in the linux terminal.

Hence, I was wondering whether there is way to start the dronekit-python api and run a specific script located on the odroid in the Mavproxy interface? As I read, this was possible in the older version (1.5), but in the update to 2.0, the dependency on Mavproxy was relaxed.",,

34,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/753,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/753/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/753/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/753/events,https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/753,258389830,MDU6SXNzdWUyNTgzODk4MzA=,753,New Feature Proposal: Optical Flow and Rangefinder for indoor missions,"{'login': 'rogerwwww', 'id': 18309862, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjE4MzA5ODYy', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars0.githubusercontent.com/u/18309862?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/rogerwwww', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/rogerwwww', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/rogerwwww/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/rogerwwww/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/rogerwwww/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/rogerwwww/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/rogerwwww/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/rogerwwww/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/rogerwwww/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/rogerwwww/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/rogerwwww/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}",[],closed,False,,[],,7,2017-09-18 07:27:58+00:00,2017-09-21 14:01:09+00:00,2017-09-21 14:01:09+00:00,NONE,,"Hi, I have succeeded in guiding my copter with **Optical Flow** and **Rangefinder** indoors, and I had several successful flights ([video here](https://youtu.be/HeJs-0_Bv8s)). My code is available [here](https://github.com/Drones4STEM/DroneController/tree/master/GUIDED).

I've modified the existing pre-flight checks to suite the OF+RF indoor environment. I've created [a subclass from ``Vehicle``](https://github.com/Drones4STEM/DroneController/blob/master/GUIDED/FlightController.py#L53), added a message listener for ``EKF_PRED_POS_HORIZ_REL`` and overloaded the ``is_armable`` attribute in class ``Vehicle``.
Are you interested in this new feature? Do you have any suggestions?

I am pretty sure that around one year ago it was working fine.
Here's a snippet of my old code:
cmds.wait_ready() # wait until download is complete.

I think CommandSequence should support negative addressing or at least correct [""Operations include â€˜array styleâ€™ indexed access to the various contained waypoints.""](http://python.dronekit.io/automodule.html) line it the docs :)",,
I was unable to find any information already online, I am running DroneKit 2.9.0 on a Rpi3 + Navio2 shield
My goal is to send ~1500 (1490) PWM to Servos 9-12 (Motors) because they are reversible and arm by receiving neutral throttle for 1 second.
# Connect to the Vehicle (in this case a tcp endpoint)
# Don't try to arm until autopilot is ready
#    print "" Waiting for vehicle to initialise...""
# Copter should arm in GUIDED mode
# Confirm vehicle armed before attempting to take off
Here is the command in question:

Additionally, I am attempting to set the mode to GUIDED_NOGPS as I am indoors and need to arm, but am only able to do this via Mission Planner. While I found this workaround any help on setting the appropriate mode in DroneKit would be appreciated as well.

,,

43,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/741,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/741/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/741/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/741/events,https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/741,245159265,MDU6SXNzdWUyNDUxNTkyNjU=,741,Copter: in angle control GUIDED mode the drone keeps rotating on its yaw axis when told not to do so,"{'login': 'deb0ch', 'id': 6248219, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjYyNDgyMTk=', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars1.githubusercontent.com/u/6248219?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/deb0ch', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/deb0ch', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/deb0ch/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/deb0ch/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/deb0ch/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/deb0ch/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/deb0ch/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/deb0ch/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/deb0ch/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/deb0ch/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/deb0ch/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}",[],closed,False,,[],,3,2017-07-24 17:54:31+00:00,2019-02-22 07:04:31+00:00,2018-01-08 09:41:10+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"#### Issue details
In GUIDED mode, using angle control with the `SET_ATTITUDE_TARGET` messages, the drone keeps rotating on its yaw axis.
It will first quickly go to a yaw angle (presumably the one set in the command's quaternion), and then will keep turning at a more or less constant rotation speed.

During another flight we even had a crash right when we passed the vehicle from LOITER to GUIDED, using the included code example with the `yaw_rate` at `2` in the parameters of `send_attitude_target`: the drone leaned very hard (maybe 45Â°) on both its pitch and roll axes, quickly losing altitude.
The `WP_YAW_BEHAVIOR` was set to `0` (`WP_YAW_BEHAVIOR_NONE`) for all those tests.
I took a couple videos using the example code below to illustrate the problem, I will include them if requested. Same with the logs, will try to find them if requested :smile:
yaw_rate,                                  # body yaw rate in radian
With this sample code constantly running, we took off in LOITER mode and then passed to GUIDED during the flight.",,

54,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/719,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/719/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/719/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/719/events,https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/719,232384460,MDU6SXNzdWUyMzIzODQ0NjA=,719,Excessive Delay when polling vehicle.attitude, etc.","{'login': 'cheintz', 'id': 8992681, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjg5OTI2ODE=', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars1.githubusercontent.com/u/8992681?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/cheintz', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/cheintz', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/cheintz/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/cheintz/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/cheintz/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/cheintz/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/cheintz/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/cheintz/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/cheintz/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/cheintz/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/cheintz/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}",[],closed,False,,[],,4,2017-05-30 21:15:45+00:00,2018-11-07 16:57:53+00:00,2018-11-07 16:57:53+00:00,NONE,,"I am working on a multi-agent fixed wing UAV formation project. The agents share information over UDP broadcast via a raspberry pi v3B. In the main control thread, I poll various attributes (attitude, position, channels, etc) and am using roll angle as a test case for debugging.

I have found (by profiling) that the program spends the overwhelming majority of time waiting (to have a reasonable sampling time). This is expected. I have found that as the other threads consume resources (not many resources, but some), the reads, to, say, vehicle.attitude.roll produce values that are delayed by up to about 1.5 seconds. The resulting values are generally unique, but lag behind real-time by that amount.

I dug into the code, and it looks like a queue is being used in mavlink.py to get messages from pymavlink to dronekit. I suspect this queue is not being emptied fast enough. If this is, in fact, a likely cause, what is the cleanest way manually process all messages in this queue to get real-time data into the vehicle object?

EDIT: I should add: the delay becomes worse with time (within an execution) and seems to persist between runs. I am connected to a PX4 over USB and have set the SR0_BAUD parameter to 1500 (1.5Mbps) and connect with the argument baud=1500000.

EDIT2: I have configured the PX4 to send messages at 20hz.  I was able to reduce the load on other threads enough that this is no longer an immediate problem. A change to processes may be in my future if I need more. This does not solve the underlying problem of the received MAVlink message queue getting backed up and having no way to know this or prioritize newer messages.",,

In dronekit-pyhton project in file mavlink.py, there is a monkey patch on the mavlink send method to add extra processing (target fixing). fixed mavmsg is retransmitted back in original mavlink send function, but  unfortunately, all other parameters (kwargs) are transmitted back as dictionary params.

I found this bug while trying to activate mavlink2 between SITL and my dronekit script: Whatever i tried, sent mavlink messages where always in V1. With this fix i could achieve mavlink 2 communication",,"{'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/pulls/699', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/699', 'diff_url': 'https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/699.diff', 'patch_url': 'https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/699.patch'}"

I have an ErleCopter 3, to which I'm connecting from my laptop either over wifi or network cable. I want to remotely control my drone from my laptop using DroneKit and a network connection.
I'm running a simple program which just tries to connect to the drone:
Regardless the ip and the port (I've made sure that I used the right ones, tried with both tcp and udp), as long as it is a remote ip address, it fails with the exception:

If DroneKit is supposed to act as a server, how does APM initiate the connection then ? Or does it ?
Is remote connection over network simply not supported, or did I miss a step / port / whatever ?",,

76,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/686,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/686/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/686/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/686/events,https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/686,194360884,MDU6SXNzdWUxOTQzNjA4ODQ=,686,Implementation of Gazebo in ROS with DroneKit-SITL ,"{'login': 'munkarkin96', 'id': 23369023, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjIzMzY5MDIz', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars3.githubusercontent.com/u/23369023?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/munkarkin96', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/munkarkin96', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/munkarkin96/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/munkarkin96/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/munkarkin96/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/munkarkin96/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/munkarkin96/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/munkarkin96/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/munkarkin96/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/munkarkin96/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/munkarkin96/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}",[],closed,False,,[],,1,2016-12-08 15:13:33+00:00,2016-12-08 18:50:53+00:00,2016-12-08 18:50:53+00:00,NONE,,"DroneKit provides such a modular and powerful platform for building of UAVs. With DroneKit-SITL, 2D simulation can help developers to clearly visualise the behaviour of the vehicle, and will tend to succeed with extensive error checking in the script.

However, the problem arises with the vehicle flying indoor. A 2 dimensional simulation is no longer sufficient, and the application demands for more extensive simulation in 3D using Gazebo, for instance.
It will be relatively useful to be able to CAD a virtual environment for indoor flying, which will be very useful for applications such as:
1. Navigating in a tunnel with constant wind disturbances
4. Visualisation of computer vision related work
and the list goes on and on.
Does the team behind this open-sourced platform has any intention of implementing the Gazebo simulator? O",,

01:33:56+00:00,NONE,,"I need to use RC overrides to send interruption command in autonomous collision avoidance flight. When RC is turned on, I can set the desired throttle value using vehicle.channels.overrides['3'] = someValue. But when RC is off, when I send a new value to vehicle.channels.overrides['3'], the vehicle disarmed immediately.  The new value is set successfully.
I may not need RC in my project. Because I want the drone to complete a mission and avoid collision automatically without any human interference. Is there any way to get rid of RC ?

,,

Obviously being inside we cannot get gps lock so we wanted to set the forwards values and backwards e.c.t. to the drone over the channel override system but the sent values aren't held.
Is there a way to get the sent values to hold their value until we clear it and if not perhaps it would be valuable to have this?

22:57:03+00:00,MEMBER,,"This enables udpin-multi mode, you can now setup dronekit to allow udpin from multiple sources, I have personally tested with up to 4, its not a hard limit its just what i was testing with, didn't really test with more but I'm sure we can support them as long as host has resources.
This feature is particularly special since it allows you to write a poor man's *`telem_forwarder`, this means we can now replicate some of its features in a cross-os environment w/o porting it.

*`telem_forwarder` is a service that lives inside 3DR Solo in between all of its responsibilities it allows you to write back to a `udpin` source from multiple clients and streams back mavlink to you from the port you started writing to.

@peterbarker I think you are going to want to review this since you have experience with `telem_forwarder`, this is specially important to us right now for development, let me know if you can't review.

I'm using `set_position_target_local_ned_encode` on `vehicle.message_factory` to move the drone, and its generally working, but, the movements are not very precise, for example I attempted to move the drone 10cm, and it moved 48cm.
1. Does `set_position_target_local_ned_encode` work without the use of GPS?
2. How should `set_position_target_local_ned_encode` be used for precise movements?

Currently I'm calling `set_position_target_local_ned_encode` every 100ms with a new velocity, on a curve, from 0 upto a max velocity and back to 0, where the integral of the curve is the distance I want to travel.

17,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/622,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/622/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/622/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/622/events,https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/622,153173763,MDU6SXNzdWUxNTMxNzM3NjM=,622,Support setting yaw rate and yaw acceleration,"{'login': 'waTeim', 'id': 5779395, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjU3NzkzOTU=', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars3.githubusercontent.com/u/5779395?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/waTeim', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/waTeim', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/waTeim/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/waTeim/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/waTeim/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/waTeim/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/waTeim/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/waTeim/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/waTeim/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/waTeim/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/waTeim/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}",[],closed,False,,[],,4,2016-05-05 06:09:33+00:00,2016-05-17 01:56:46+00:00,2016-05-16 11:37:47+00:00,NONE,,"This feature is needed to preserve a smooth feel in response to target angle change while recording video.  Without it, the scene has a ""jerky"" feel and the subject move across the field of view instead of staying centered.  Importantly in contrast to upstream discussion that appear to talk about a global setting, this would need to be settable per command.
Some documentation from the various examples in particular; currently this appears to be unsupported but the example documentation might be old and the issues are closed.

`The parameters allow you to specify whether the target direction is absolute or relative to the current yaw direction. If the direction is relative you can also (separately) specify whether the value is added or subtracted from the current heading (note that the vehicle will always turn in direction that most quickly gets it to the new target heading regardless of the param3 value).`
`We donâ€™t support controlling the yaw rate, so the param2 value (Sec) is ignored.`
velocity_z, # Z velocity in NED frame in m/s
0, 0, 0, # afx, afy, afz acceleration (not supported yet, ignored in GCS_Mavlink)
0, 0)    # yaw, yaw_rate (not supported yet, ignored in GCS_Mavlink)
This is apparently a requested feature upstream. includes ArduPilot/ardupilot#1635, ArduPilot/ardupilot#1758

Since I cannot get a good GPS signal indoors, I disable GPS check in the pre-arm checks by going into Mission planner and:
1. Unchecking it from arming checks list in the standard parameters
2. Setting AHRS_GPS_USE to 0 and Arming check to -9 in the full parameters list.

Problem: Now when I try to arm the drone using the conventional method as shown in the dronekit python documentation it shows: ""Prearm: Need 3D fix"". However, if I arm using my RC controller, it arms.  This is somehow pointing to the fact that somehow dronekit-python still performs a GPS 3D fix check even if we set it in the mission planner to ignore the GPS check. I am not sure if this is the case, but my experiments are pointing towards this fact. Hence, can somebody kindly provide some insight into this matter. I appreciate all of your time and help in advance.
Versions of the platform in use --

False}]",,4,2016-04-02 00:15:00+00:00,2016-06-14 22:17:20+00:00,2016-06-14 22:17:12+00:00,NONE,,"this is what I am trying to do:
I am trying to write a python script which will control my drone (quadcopter + pixhawk).
but as a safety precaution I want to use joystick.
So, I will be setting a switch on joystick which should control/switch between joystick control and my script control.

This patch handles errors consistently with how they are handled at a higher level (in `mavlink_thread_in`). A more robust error handling mechanism (with configurable logging) is desired, but this patch is more essential for now.

So for example, if I load mission into Copter which is 2 waypoints, within ardupilot there will be 3 items in the command list: home, wp1, wp2.  It's arguably bad behaviour that command-0 is always home but this is besides the point.  From the dronekit user's point of view, when the command list is retrieved, there are actually 3 items that he/she can iterate over but the count is only 2.  this will lead people to not read the last command.

58,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/570,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/570/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/570/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/570/events,https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/570,134710810,MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0NTk4NzE3Nzg=,570,Splits outbound messages into its own thread.,"{'login': 'tcr3dr', 'id': 12703357, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjEyNzAzMzU3', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars2.githubusercontent.com/u/12703357?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/tcr3dr', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}",[],closed,False,,[],,10,2016-02-18 22:10:07+00:00,2016-02-19 08:09:52+00:00,2016-02-19 07:46:13+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"We maintain a separate thread for outbound messages so that the main thread as well as the reading thread can send messages.

Right now outbound messages are sent in lockstep with reading messages; this actually creates huge problems with high-rate telemetry (on Solo proper). Splitting it into a concurrent thread passes tests but also improves output rate greatly.

00:28:52+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"Rebased and tested this: https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/513
I used a real quad for testing this; mount simulation needs work.
I found duplication in a try/catch so I removed it.
I used `API Error` as the comment above the error that is thrown since `dronekit.APIException` is fairly vague and not much can be deduced from that.
Would it be preferred for this comment to be more descriptive?

I am very new to this and am struggling! My current set up is too have an Ubuntu guest running the SITL and using the UDP port to communicate with mission planner on the windows host machine. I am writing code for a autonomous tracking mission for a university project and constructing the code in sublime text 2. I have installed dronekit-python every i could find in guides etc but when ever i try to 'import dronekit' or 'from dronekit import VehicleModes' and run the script in mission planner, an error of ""Error running script unexpected token ' "". Am i using it in the correct way? are there any work arounds? Thank you very much for your time

,,

I want to simulate a cyber attack by setting a constant bias on achieved/actual rotor rate while the autopilot is commanding a different rotor rate. I came across the  [chanenel overrides](http://python.dronekit.io/examples/channel_overrides.html) which seems like it might be useful to me. My question is to ask if this is a viable approach for simulating a cyber attack on a UAV? Are there other options/avenues to pursue which would be easier/safer? I am not particularly familiar with the Dronekit API, but will be using it a lot this semester.

,,

an alternative method of installing pip, prior to installing dronekit.

The [original suggestion](https://gitter.im/dronekit/dronekit-python?at=56ac5b976c947b2d74ba54f0) was to replace apt-get with easy_install, but from my reading it looks like this has its own potential issues and might not be as familiar for some users. Instead I have left the quick start alone, but I have outlined both approaches in the more detailed installation instructions.
This should highlight the alternative if developers have problem with the ""more modern"" method.

As per DKP2.0, we have the option to modify the home_location.
I have tried changing the home_location, but nothing happens. I have tried

Left alt as None here, also tried to use the same alt as the initial home_location. Didn't work. However, the above threw an error because I couldn't use float values for lat_value and lon_value. Why is that though? I came across the above in a script which was meant for SITL. Is that the reason?
> Commands to change a value are not guaranteed to succeed (or even to be received) and code should be written with this in mind.

So am I required to wait for the pixhawk to accept the change? Whatever I tried from the above, didn't really post an error. When I tried to read off the new home_location after setting it to a new one, it just returned me the original home_location. So what's required for this? (Seems an important issue with this added feature as per me)

5,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/513,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/513/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/513/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/513/events,https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/513,126067381,MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0NTU2OTc0Mzc=,513,Fix mount status to return float degrees, not int degrees","{'login': 'njoubert', 'id': 181043, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjE4MTA0Mw==', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars1.githubusercontent.com/u/181043?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/njoubert', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/njoubert', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/njoubert/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/njoubert/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/njoubert/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/njoubert/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/njoubert/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/njoubert/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/njoubert/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/njoubert/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/njoubert/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}",[],closed,False,,[],,6,2016-01-12 00:07:21+00:00,2016-02-08 22:58:26+00:00,2016-02-08 22:58:26+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"Currently MOUNT_STATUS returns integer degrees. But the MAVLINK message sends it as integer centi-degrees, so we're losing two orders of magnitude in precision. This fix changes MOUNT_STATUS to return float values.

7,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/510,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/510/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/510/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/510/events,https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/510,125709829,MDU6SXNzdWUxMjU3MDk4Mjk=,510,Differences between vehicle.commands.goto and vehicle.simple_goto (GUIDED mode),{'login': 'sahiljuneja', 'id': 12501638, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjEyNTAxNjM4', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars1.githubusercontent.com/u/12501638?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/sahiljuneja', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/sahiljuneja', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/sahiljuneja/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/sahiljuneja/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/sahiljuneja/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/sahiljuneja/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/sahiljuneja/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/sahiljuneja/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/sahiljuneja/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/sahiljuneja/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/sahiljuneja/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}",[],closed,False,,[],,1,2016-01-08 22:43:49+00:00,2016-01-19 10:39:35+00:00,2016-01-19 10:39:35+00:00,NONE,,"Hello,
I believe in the most recent ""major update"" for DKP2.0, there were changes made to the goto and takeoff commands. I have tested out DKP1.0 and then DKP2.0 before this update.

If I set a GPS location for the drone to go to, followed by another GPS location after reaching the first one, all I had to do was define the command with the GPS coordinates, and then queue up the next command. And it would fly to the first point, and then to the next one. I didn't have to add any checks to ensure that the drone had indeed reached the first GPS position before executing the next command. I thought there was an internal check in your of Pixhawk's code.
Now I am testing the latest DPK2.0 release with the changes to the commands - vehicle.simple_goto.
I repeat the above process, but this time, the next command is getting executed immediately. Which causes erratic behaviour

There's no apparent change in my code. So I wonder what the difference is between the two. If there isn't, then this behaviour is bit odd since the difference lies within me shifting to DKP2.0 only. (I will try to backtrack my code as well in the mean time just to be sure.)

,,

I split out a new section ""Developing with DroneKit"" which covers installation (cut down topic), simulation, companion computers, coding standards. Still to do in this are ""best practise"" and updating Simulation topic to use DK-Sitl.

The guide is now pure ""how to use the API"". This starts with a separate ""Connection"" topic. This is OK, but I will update that connection topic further in a later revision (this is much easier to do now it is a stand-alone topic).
All links have been fixed up.
# Don't let the user try to arm until autopilot is ready
print "" Waiting for vehicle to initialise...""
# Copter should arm in GUIDED mode
# Wait until the vehicle reaches a safe height before processing the goto (otherwise the command
#Break and return from function just below target altitude.
- release(): give back rc control of gimbal
Documentation may need some work. And we may want to add type checks
I apologize for the messed up commit. It appears my text editor went to town on white spaces.

Calling `connect` hangs the program indefinitely when I use a udp connection string (""udp:172.28.128.1:5760"", which is how I connect to a vagrant instance of SITL). I've traced it, and it appears to be caused by the `import array` on line 26 in pymavlink/generator/mavcrc.py. Moving the import to the top of the file seems to fix the issue. I suspect it may be a threading issue because that function is called on a separate thread.
Also, I'm using the latest version of dronekit and pymavlink from pip, and this also occurs on dronekit master.

39,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/470,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/470/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/470/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/470/events,https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/470,117875569,MDU6SXNzdWUxMTc4NzU1Njk=,470,Future-proofing goto and takeoff,"{'login': 'tcr3dr', 'id': 12703357, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjEyNzAzMzU3', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars2.githubusercontent.com/u/12703357?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/tcr3dr', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}","[{'id': 88720673, 'node_id': 'MDU6TGFiZWw4ODcyMDY3Mw==', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/labels/enhancement', 'name': 'enhancement', 'color': '84b6eb', 'default': True, 'description': None}]",closed,False,,[],,3,2015-11-19 18:19:48+00:00,2015-11-20 18:12:57+00:00,2015-11-20 18:12:57+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"Last chance for future-proofing DKPY2!

We probably want the namespace `vehicle.commands.goto` and `.takeoff` in the future for waypoints. We may also want `vehicle.takeoff` and `vehicle.goto` as immediate commands with more complex behavior than what we support now.
I propose we change the current functions to `vehicle.simple_goto` and `vehicle.simple_takeoff` so that we
1. Preserve all examples that work now
2. Free up the namespace in the future to have more properly and thoughtfully implemented commands.

This is obviously weird to use the ""simple"" prefix but it would prevent us from doing a major version bump if we ever wanted to reclaim these function names. Weâ€™ll just deprecate (but not remove) the `simple_*` variants when we have suitable replacements.

In the way `.goto` is currently implemented, APM just ignores information about relative vs absolute location and defaults to absolute. This can be considered a bug, [or our use of MISSION_ITEM can be considered a hack](https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/drones-discuss/_UmqPM5b_60), and either way, we want a solution that works yesterday. For now, this restores the expected behavior, with minimal side effects (hopefully).

This means that if you pass it a LocationGlobal and say ""goto"" it will fly to that position ABOVE the home position (rather than mean sea level).
Internally we need to detect we're dealing with a global and pass in the associated relative alt.

Exposing `source_system` might be, though.

This does a bit of an overhaul over the MAVLink object in the backend to make sure we get this right. The `target_system` is loaded from the first heartbeat we get and fixed after that point. We also have some backend classes which we might expose eventually, but for now demonstrate the use of multiple target systems in one program. e.g.
Works to daisy chain a connection _through_ DroneKit. This is obviously using undocumented features (MAVConnection directly) but demonstrates the logic should work if we expose it publicly later.

@tcr3dr This states that the vehicle target system is used to set the values used in `Command` and in `send_mavlink`.

52,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/455,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/455/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/455/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/455/events,https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/455,117051800,MDU6SXNzdWUxMTcwNTE4MDA=,455,API explanations in the top level Vehicle or convenience classes?,"{'login': 'hamishwillee', 'id': 5368500, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjUzNjg1MDA=', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars2.githubusercontent.com/u/5368500?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/hamishwillee', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}","[{'id': 213117949, 'node_id': 'MDU6TGFiZWwyMTMxMTc5NDk=', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/labels/[docs]%20question', 'name': '[docs] question', 'color': '006b75', 'default': False, 'description': None}]",closed,False,,[],,3,2015-11-16 04:59:48+00:00,2015-11-16 23:56:58+00:00,2015-11-16 23:56:58+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"If you have an attribute like `vehicle.heading` which represents a single value there is just one place where it can be documented.
For a compound object like `Vehicle.location` you can have the documentation in the top level attribute or spread in the sub classes like `Locations`, `LocationGlobal`, `LocationGlobalRelative` etc.

Having most of the docs up in the top level `vehicle` makes sense because you mostly operate on the attributes through this object, but it does mean that you can't easily scan through `Vehicle` to see the available attributes and then dig down for functionality. This wouldn't matter so much if there was a class listing in the sidebar (as requested) but it is a bit of a pain as we don't.

Most of all though, it is important to try be consistent. My leaning is to have most of the documents in the top level `Vehicle`, with minimal documentation in ""sub attributes"" (and hope our docs infrastructure improves).
@tcr3dr @mrpollo Do you have any opinion on this?

'2015-12-29T21:41:17Z', 'due_on': None, 'closed_at': None}",9,2015-11-12 12:33:50+00:00,2015-11-18 21:22:13+00:00,2015-11-18 19:50:18+00:00,NONE,,"Under DKPY1, this was raised: https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/112
DKPY2 already appears to monitor heartbeat status, but there's no way to directly acess it, or (it seems) reliably detect an active connection.
For example, I fI run vehicle.close(), I can still access all of the saved data and there's no clear indication I've lost my connection.
Just being able to see either time of last heartbeat or time since last heartbeat would allow the user to manage timeouts themselves with staged behaviour.
I see there's an exception thrown, but that's after 30s (which isn't customisable). IF you want to catch a timeout before that, you don't appear to have an option.

This adds a `SystemStatus` property which functions similarly to `VehicleMode`, in that it is a light wrapper around a string (really an enum).
This is a breaking change with earlier rc's in that it used to be a number from mavutil, and is no longer.

The goal is ""the correct way for users to implement custom attributes"". I rewrote this example to leverage the vehicle_class property of connect to instantiate a custom Vehicle class. The Vehicle constructor works similarly to how the internal ones, allowing you to add private properties, message listeners, etc. that become part of the class definition.

I recommend this as the definitive way downstream users implement custom properties, as it's similar to how internal extensions like [dronekit-python-solo](https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python-solo) do it.
