'2015-12-29T21:41:17Z', 'due_on': None, 'closed_at': None}",5,2015-11-07 10:39:31+00:00,2015-11-17 21:32:08+00:00,2015-11-17 21:32:08+00:00,NONE,,"I was testing out the connection timeout, and came across an odd behaviour.  If I set the timeout > 10 seconds, everything works nicely - it hapily throws an APIException that I can catch.

However, if I set the connection timeout lower than that, it throws a different exception, seemingly from somewhere ""inside"" the connection, and it's an ""Exception"" rather than an ""APIException"".
Is this the intent?  I reported it here: https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/407 and was requested to submit it as a new issue.
If I set timeout to 10 or more, it works fine. If less than that, it throws the following:
Link timeout, no heartbeat in last 5 seconds
raise Exception('>>> No heartbeat in %s seconds, aborting.' % self._heartbea
Exception: >>> No heartbeat in 9 seconds, aborting.
It looks like setting timeout too low interferes with or gets inside some other exception handling loop.

(magic, self.expected_length) = struct.unpack('BB', str(self.buf[0:2])) # bytearrays are not supported in py 2.7.3

This is incorrect
You can see the behaviour by observing mission_basic.py example (note we're reporting next waypoint as 0 (incorrect), then the system reports we've reached waypoint 1 (correctly)
As an aside, this causes the example to misreport the distance to the next waypoint (and rather report the distance from the last waypoint)

'2015-12-29T21:41:17Z', 'due_on': None, 'closed_at': None}",8,2015-11-04 21:23:52+00:00,2015-11-11 00:48:11+00:00,2015-11-11 00:18:06+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"Considering the GPS and EKF issues exposed by #406, I wonder if we shouldn't be exposing a different parameter indicating ""readiness to arm"".
In several of our examples, we sidestep this by waiting for a GPS lock. e.g. in simple_goto:
# Don't let the user try to fly autopilot is booting
We discover with 3.3 we also need to wait for an EKF readiness flag. What if we were instead to abstract several of these considerations into an attribute, `vehicle.armable`:
This would encompass the MODE, GPS, and (depending on vehicle?) EKF checks, so that we can have a simple mechanism to wait for this (instead of our crufty spin-loops).

,,

'2015-12-29T21:41:17Z', 'due_on': None, 'closed_at': None}",6,2015-11-04 11:21:59+00:00,2015-11-17 21:31:37+00:00,2015-11-17 21:31:37+00:00,NONE,,"It appears that there's no timeout for the ""connect"" function.  If you try to connect to a serial port that exists but is not actually connected to a vehicle, it just hangs.

On the RasPi, I'm conecting to the Pixhawk via USB, so it's /dev/ttyACM0. The RasPi has a built in serial port at ttyAMA0. If you ""Connect('/dev/ttyAM0')"" it hangs, presumably because it's a valid port so it thinks it can read, but never gets valid data.

22:24:12+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"As of DK 2.0.0 rc7, examples that utilize observer methods will fail because they are still using the old syntax and logic.
To fix the the issue, all examples using observer methods need the following changes:
Examples on python.dronekit.io need to be updated as well.

92,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/412,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/412/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/412/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/412/events,https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/412,114951491,MDU6SXNzdWUxMTQ5NTE0OTE=,412,HDOP incorrectly represented in cm in the Documentation,{'login': 'jainakshay91', 'id': 13305568, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjEzMzA1NTY4', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars2.githubusercontent.com/u/13305568?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jainakshay91', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/jainakshay91', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jainakshay91/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jainakshay91/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jainakshay91/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jainakshay91/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jainakshay91/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jainakshay91/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jainakshay91/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jainakshay91/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/jainakshay91/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}",[],closed,False,,[],,20,2015-11-04 01:52:59+00:00,2015-11-06 02:18:15+00:00,2015-11-06 02:16:20+00:00,NONE,,"Hi, is the HDOP value returned by dronekit-python from gps_0.eph actually in centimeters ?

As much as I remember, a DOP value is just a factor and is a unitless quantity. Further, most GPS receivers supply information in the NMEA format. Now the GPGGA message in the NMEA protocol which provides the HDOP information says that there is no unit to this quantity (reference: [ublox protocol manual](https://www2.u-blox.com/images/downloads/Product_Docs/u-blox7-V14_ReceiverDescriptionProtocolSpec_Public_%28GPS.G7-SW-12001%29.pdf) page 67).

Next, since the [AP_GPS_NMEA.cpp](https://github.com/diydrones/ardupilot/blob/master/libraries/AP_GPS/AP_GPS_NMEA.cpp#L310) is used to precisely parse these NMEA messages and then pack them into the mavlink protocol messages, I cannot find a step where these HDOP (unitless) values are converted to cm. The function to parse these messgaes:_parse_decimal_100() is a generic function which is also used for parsing the time and altitude information. In the definition of _parse_decimal_100() it states that there is a theoretical resolution of upto 1 cm and hence I think there is this confusion with the units of the HDOP value.  Kindly let me know thoughts and comments on this issue.

3,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/401,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/401/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/401/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/401/events,https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/pull/401,114740783,MDExOlB1bGxSZXF1ZXN0NDk1MTkxNTY=,401,Extracts MPState object logic into Vehicle. Implements wait_ready.,"{'login': 'tcr3dr', 'id': 12703357, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjEyNzAzMzU3', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars2.githubusercontent.com/u/12703357?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/tcr3dr', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}",[],closed,False,,[],,8,2015-11-03 04:44:41+00:00,2015-11-03 23:02:28+00:00,2015-11-03 18:33:04+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"This is a pretty heavy PR, but also the last major refactor I have planned.

Rather than obtusely split parameter logic between a MAVLink handler and a Vehicle object, the Vehicle object (through ""message"" handlers and ""event loop"" handlers) now implements all of its own core logic inside the class. There is still some slightly awkward coupling going on between the classes, but there's far less of it, and the code to manage properties is all in one place.

As a side effect of this, we're now able to track the status of most attributes, and as such have a working `wait_ready` implementation on the vehicle that serves as the basis for `await_param` (which should be deprecated and replaced) as well as other methods like `wait_valid`, etc.

Additionally, we get rid of the MAVLink rx handlers and only expose the `on_message` primitive, which acts as our MAVLink interaction story. Ideally, we can abstract the message contruction story as well, though I haven't put much thought into it.

message_factory, the correct system id must be specified, otherwise it won't work.
This was tested using the following code:
However, changing the system id to the proper value (1 in this case) fixes the problem.
The documentation suggests that this should be automatically taken care of by send_mavlink(), yet it does't seem to be the case.
I tried the same code with dronekit 1 and it does indeed work without the need to specify the sysid manually.

Fixes #393.,{'login': 'tcr3dr', 'id': 12703357, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjEyNzAzMzU3', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars2.githubusercontent.com/u/12703357?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/tcr3dr', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}",[],closed,False,,[],,0,2015-11-02 21:38:12+00:00,2015-11-02 22:30:03+00:00,2015-11-02 22:30:02+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"This adds a `baud=` parameter to connect(), with the exact semantics of `mavlink_connection`.

We also adopt the mavutil reconnection logic rather than forcibly recreating the network, in order to preserve the baud (and what other) properties. The Windows test needs this most often due to it running slowly, so if Appveyor passes, then we are successful.

10,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/393,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/393/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/393/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/393/events,https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/393,114680904,MDU6SXNzdWUxMTQ2ODA5MDQ=,393,"DKPY2:  autopilot baudrate locked to 115200, should be configurable","{'login': 'a7scenario', 'id': 12090430, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjEyMDkwNDMw', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars0.githubusercontent.com/u/12090430?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/a7scenario', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/a7scenario', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/a7scenario/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/a7scenario/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/a7scenario/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/a7scenario/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/a7scenario/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/a7scenario/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/a7scenario/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/a7scenario/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/a7scenario/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}",[],closed,False,,[],,3,2015-11-02 20:49:05+00:00,2015-11-03 00:48:53+00:00,2015-11-02 22:30:02+00:00,NONE,,"In DroneKit Python ver. 2 (DKPY2), the connect() function uses mavutil's mavlink_connection function to open a serial connection to the autopilot.  The issue is that connect's call to mavlink_connection doesn't specify a baudrate and, therefore, mavlink_connection just uses its default baudrate of 115200.  If I'm not mistaken, this means there is no way to change the baudrate of the connection between a Companion Computer and an autopilot if you're using DKPY2.  It would be better if connect() added an input argument of baudrate=115200 that it relays to mavlink_connection, to allow for using different baudrates with your autopilot.
def connect(ip , await_params=False, status_printer=errprinter, vehicle_class=Vehicle, rate=4):

27,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/376,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/376/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/376/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/376/events,https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/376,113543555,MDU6SXNzdWUxMTM1NDM1NTU=,376,Cannot upload waypoints,"{'login': 'hamishwillee', 'id': 5368500, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjUzNjg1MDA=', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars2.githubusercontent.com/u/5368500?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/hamishwillee', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}",[],closed,False,,[],,1,2015-10-27 09:41:18+00:00,2015-11-02 21:41:32+00:00,2015-11-02 21:41:32+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"In dronekit 2.0.0c1 running on windows the examples mission_basic.py and mission_import_export.py demonstrate that command uploading is not working. Clearing waypoints works, downloading waypoints works, going into auto mode for an existing set of waypoints works, but uploading new waypoints does not.

In mission_basic.py this was checked by running the example while watching in MP, and adding a line to look at the current mode. The example clears existing waypoints and then attempts to upload new ones. The waypoints are visibly cleared, but the new ones are not uploade/visible in mission planner. As a result the example get stuck when ""starting the mission"" because the autopilot will not allow you to change to auto mode if there are no waypoints.
mission_import_export.py similarly shows that after uploading the new set of waypoints, if you download them again you get nothing back.
I tried this on two versions of SITL and verified that waypoints can be written using MP. This code worked in dk1.5.

- Removes flush usage except from when adding and clearing commands ( so not during takeoff etc). I THINK it is needed when clearing!
- Fixes up the API reference so that the public API as it is now is visible (ie hides APIConnection etc, adds connect)
- Fixes up guide and API reference to use the LocationGlobal class
The last was quite tough and there will be more work to be done (for example the guided mode can be smarter now that we have LocationLocal objects).
This does not use or update vehiclemode docs (for equality comparisons). I am hoping you will review and publish this set of docs asap.

'2015-12-29T21:41:17Z', 'due_on': None, 'closed_at': None}",6,2015-10-26 05:53:47+00:00,2015-11-11 00:23:25+00:00,2015-11-11 00:23:25+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"The normal ""arm and takeoff"" code (as per [simple_goto.py](https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/blob/master/examples/simple_goto/simple_goto.py#L29) example) checks that state is not initialising and that we have a good GPS fix. Then it changes the mode to GUIDED and tries to arm the vehicle.

On the Windows Copter 3.3 dronekit-sitl build this script successfully arms and takes off if you've waited a bit or already connected to mission planner. However if you start the script shortly after the simulator it never arms. This means that there is something the autopilot is waiting on before we can arm - if you call the command to ARM before this ""thing"" completes the device will never arm.

If you add a delay of around 8 seconds after the vehicle changes to guided, but before calling ARM then the vehicle will ARM. If you just call ARM repeatedly in the loop while waiting for it to arm this also works. To me this again indicates that there is something that we need to wait on before calling ARM.

Any ideas what it might be? The ""easy"" solution for the example is to just set arm to true in the loop - but this is pretty crap - much better to identify whatever pre-arm condition is stopping us from proceeding.

This includes adding vehicle.close and connect, and making the example docs follow the same pattern as the other example docs.
- This does not work! There is an exception due to #355 . The docs have a note to this effect. When the bug is fixed we'll have to revisit and retest the docs/code.

I can't get the drone_delivery example to work. I've [updated it in this gist](https://gist.github.com/hamishwillee/22102fe31c3473c3a36e). Unfortunately it won't take off because the command to change the mode to guided never succeeds - it just sits there in the wrong mode.
The same code run in a ""normal"" environment does work - you can test this by just enabling [this line](https://gist.github.com/hamishwillee/22102fe31c3473c3a36e#file-drone_delivery-py-L82).

I have also seen cases while experimenting where I changed the mode manually in the simulator via mavproxy, and this change was not detected - though the system sat there telling me it was getting the wrong mode.
I've tried lots of ""trial and error"" but I can't work out why it works in one case and not the other. Needs debugging from someone who can check the messages are actually being sent.

As a side note, I don't think this would have ever worked prior to this update because there was no code to get the vehicle to take off, and because one of the checks on whether or not to run the loop to get GPS would never have run.
This was tested in a simulated environment using simulated gps :-)

49,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/352,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/352/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/352/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/352/events,https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/352,111753336,MDU6SXNzdWUxMTE3NTMzMzY=,352,Mavlink callback handler only receiving parameters for first 20 seconds,"{'login': 'hamishwillee', 'id': 5368500, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjUzNjg1MDA=', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars2.githubusercontent.com/u/5368500?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/hamishwillee', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}",[],closed,False,,[],,8,2015-10-16 03:48:51+00:00,2015-11-10 01:09:36+00:00,2015-11-09 22:19:15+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"The Mavlink callback handler (set using `set_mavlink_callback`) is receiving only PARAM_VALUE messages for the first 20 seconds (or so) after connecting, even when `await_params=True` has been set for the connection.

I've run some tests and confirmed that the parameter array is populated after the connection completes (just printed some values after the connection). I think this means that something in our startup code is possibly re-requesting these parameters.
This breaks the `create_attribute.py` example because for the first 20 seconds after connecting we don't get the messages we're searching for. Its also not ""a good thing"" :-)

This can be verified by modifying the create_attribute.py example as [per this gist](https://gist.github.com/hamishwillee/960fa8804c6406b26be7). Essentially it just logs the messages received, which you can see below are all params. I ran this with a native SITL build (master, copter) from Cygwin, and with the b6 DK build.
Display RAW_IMU messages for 5 seconds and then exit.
PARAM_VALUE {param_id : RC3_MIN, param_value : 1000.0, param_type : 4, param_count : 592, param_index : 80}
PARAM_VALUE {param_id : RC3_TRIM, param_value : 1500.0, param_type : 4, param_count : 592, param_index : 81}
PARAM_VALUE {param_id : RC3_MAX, param_value : 2000.0, param_type : 4, param_count : 592, param_index : 82}
PARAM_VALUE {param_id : RC3_REV, param_value : 1.0, param_type : 2, param_count : 592, param_index : 83}
PARAM_VALUE {param_id : RC3_DZ, param_value : 30.0, param_type : 4, param_count : 592, param_index : 84}
PARAM_VALUE {param_id : RC4_MIN, param_value : 1000.0, param_type : 4, param_count : 592, param_index : 85}
PARAM_VALUE {param_id : RC4_TRIM, param_value : 1500.0, param_type : 4, param_count : 592, param_index : 86}
PARAM_VALUE {param_id : RC4_MAX, param_value : 2000.0, param_type : 4, param_count : 592, param_index : 87}

As an aside if we're reading params from the vehicle on start, how do we know they are accurate if a GCS might also change the values? Do we re-read after updating a value ourselves (or do we update the array and assume the update was successful?)

'2015-12-29T21:41:17Z', 'due_on': None, 'closed_at': None}",5,2015-10-14 12:38:04+00:00,2015-11-07 00:23:18+00:00,2015-11-07 00:23:18+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"Bikeshedding time~~~!
I feel like we want a method `.await([types], defaults=True)` that does the following:
1. Waits for system_status to enter an initialized state. This is equivalent to a `.notify_change` event on `""initialized""`. (included by default when defaults=True)
2. Waits for parameters to be loaded. This is equivalent to a `.notify_change` event on `""parameters""`. (included by default when defaults=True)
3. Waits for what other defaults? (Armed? Mode? etc.)
4. Waits for an arbitrary list of `.notify_change` events. This encompasses attributes.
So an example vehicle state example may be:

Wow, what a verbose function! But does it make sense? We want to _ensure_ these values are populated. But this example then doesn't scale if we are always waiting for a rangefinder event that doesn't happen. Maybe we want to await a selection of always-on parameters, then time-await a selection of properties that may be optional?
We can also consider the `.await()` method to be aliased in the connect function as so:
(In this case, how do you disable defaults?)

It also tidies up the ""running the example"" section on the vehicle state example.

'2015-12-29T21:41:17Z', 'due_on': None, 'closed_at': None}",11,2015-10-08 18:23:24+00:00,2015-11-09 06:52:39+00:00,2015-11-07 00:24:50+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"I think it's appropriate to remove the RC override examples in DKPY2.

My primary motivation is not that this is unsafe user behavior (it can be but that's not relevant), but rather that this does not work on Solo, which has its own pipeline for RC controls. As a result, we don't have a generic way of this working even in the case of Python code, so we may want to approach this differently in the future.

For example, the `dronekit.sitl` package can include its own RC functions (the MAVProxy module actually is fixed to SITL output anyway); `dronekit.solo` could do likewise. But Dronekit core would not include these.

tmp_getting_started_dkpy2 which will be merged in #320).
The last action in the script is RTL:
However the RTL does not occur (the command is probably not sent - certainly the MAVProxy prompt was still reporting ""guided"".
I ran this a few times. In one case I got an exception reported:
Exception in thread Thread-1 (most likely raised during interpreter shutdown):
Is there any way to ensure that the last command is fully completed (ie flush completes) before the thread exits?
Otherwise, what is the best way to deal with this? I'd prefer not to add documentation that scripts should wait a second before completing.

tmp_getting_started_dkpy2 which will be merged in #320).

The script checks for GPS being good enough before attempting to arm. This check takes about 20 seconds to complete - even if the vehicle is already flying. As you can see in the example below the GPS connection information value is None - when it returns we get the current altitude as 20.
Obviously we're not getting a GPS message for the first 20 seconds after connecting (or we're somehow dropping it). Either way this needs to be fixed.

tmp_getting_started_dkpy2 which will be merged in #320).

If I re-run the script when the vehicle is airborne the system still reports "">>> â˜ºARMING MOTORS"" etc. Yes, the script does set `vehicle.armed = True` but it is already armed and flying and the vehicle will ignore this command. So ideally in this case the message should not be shown.
Note, I appreciate that perhaps this should just be ignored. I'm just raising the issue so we make a decision and I can document the behaviour. Ditto with `Initialising APM`. Other alternatives
- change the message so that it is clear that we're sending a command only
- remove all auto-generated messages - let the script author define their own messages if needed.
I lean towards the last point, though if we were actually triggering off an arming message back from the autopilot , I might reconsider

If it is true and you're sitting at the home location altitude should be zero.

This is buggy for copter - if you look at the location value for (landed) Plane and Copter below you can see that the Copter value is broken - it should be True because we're sitting on the home position and altitude is zero.

-  [x] Confirm vehicle.command.next is witeable - #390 and doc appropriately

- [x] In migrating guide add change from await_params with wait_ready (actually mostly just doc the wai-init when downloading, but also check that wait_ready properly documented in terms of usage in the api ref, parameters and command downloads sections - #408
- [x] Update parameters documentation to explain the stuff about how parameters get populated (e.g. getting all at once or individually, values of parameters before populated. See #404.
- [x] Do a proper write up of connecting behaviour including covering waiting. This should be in our programming guide.
- [x] Update ""Running the examples"" doc to cover general instructions
- [x] Work out standard format for examples to import connect and use an option parser to take in the connection, defaulting to SITL local port
- [x] Update all examples to use above mechanism and test
- [x] Update all examples to use vehicle.close
- [x] Document explaining changes and implications of changes vs how to use the API vs v1.x
- [x] How to import connect and start a connection
- [x] No MAVProxy so how to connect
- [x] Passing options to the script now just normal arguments
- [x] Remove MAVProxy dependencies from getting started.
- [x] Change back to command line instructions on windows
- [x] Update the actual dependencies of dk-python (ie remove mavproxy dependencies not needed by dk-python).
- [x] add this in the API Ref
- [x] add this in the migrating doc.
- [x] add this in all the examples (done, but in a number of pull requests - not yet in master)

- [x] UPdate **mission_basic.py**, **mission_import_export.py** and **flight_replay.py** examples when [#355](https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/355) is fixed. Both fail. The later says so in the docs and that will need to be tidied. The former does nto.

'2015-12-29T21:41:17Z', 'due_on': None, 'closed_at': None}",1,2015-08-17 06:52:26+00:00,2015-11-11 22:07:49+00:00,2015-11-11 22:07:49+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"The vehicle_state.py example fails with
TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for /: 'NoneType' and 'float'

I think this is is due to a race condition. We are getting the Battery object before it is initialised with a real value. The result is a divide by None error because the default value is set to None in the interface. You can reproduce this using code like below ... and if you uncomment the timer before the print for a few seconds the error does not occur.

Note also that on startup all the values are None because they haven't had a chance to initialise with values. I kind of feel we shouldn't return from the vehicle call until we have got some vehicle information ....

following code should pretty much connect then close
# Get the connected vehicle (currently only one vehicle can be returned).
What it does instead is print:
VIBRATION {time_usec : 4360865000, vibration_x : 0.0, vibration_y : 0.0, vibration_z : 0.0, clipping_0 : 0, clipping_1 : 0, clipping_2 : 0}
VIBRATION {time_usec : 4361105000, vibration_x : 0.0, vibration_y : 0.0, vibration_z : 0.0, clipping_0 : 0, clipping_1 : 0, clipping_2 : 0}
VIBRATION {time_usec : 4378145000, vibration_x : 0.0, vibration_y : 0.0, vibration_z : 0.0, clipping_0 : 0, clipping_1 : 0, clipping_2 : 0}
So there is some unwanted output of rangefinder and vibration. I would also say that these messages are not needed - the user should add ""connected"" or whatever as soon as they have a vehicle.

The dronekit documentation should make it clear that, if the user uses the Windows installer, MAVProxy (and dronekit) will not have visibility of the user's default Python environment. Any extra Python modules they wish to use should be copied into the MAVProxy folder.

You can however compare `Vehicle.mode.name == VehicleMode('GUIDED').name`

I've put this in the API reference for the Mode because we don't have a better place. I made a conscious decision to not document attributes separately in the guide, but instead to put documentation in the class (if there is one) and the Vehicle attribute itself if there isn't an associated class.
This was to address the specific comment https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/278#issuecomment-130138613

In addition it adds a (pretty cool :-) ) example and docs of how to add your own attributes to the Vehicle class in a script.

Unlike the other examples, the example doc has quite a lot of explanation - I decided that in this case it made sense because it extends the callback functionality. I have linked to it from the guide though.
Let me know what you think.

The biggest issue with the current implementation is:
This means that determining which mode you are in either requires you to make your own enum:
Or access the `name` field (which is not documented):
Additionally, being an enum would allow for code that checks whether a given mode exists programmatically:
and to iterate through the available enums:
The type of enum I have in mind is detailed in [this StackOverflow post](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/36932/how-can-i-represent-an-enum-in-python)

False}]",,11,2015-08-10 06:55:03+00:00,2015-11-09 22:35:57+00:00,2015-11-09 21:37:43+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"`set_mavlink_callback` allows users to intercept all messages to the companion computer/script, so it is arguably\* quite useful for adding support for messages or ""attributes"" that aren't yet in the API. The proposal is to update the example to provide a ""useful"" reference for people who want to create their own message handlers.

- I say ""arguably"" because it is similar effort to update the API to do this properly. So you would only use this while waiting on changes to go into the API ""properly"". The example would co-exist with an enhancement to the contribution section providing step-by step guidance on how to support a new attribute. The instructions would make it clear that the best approach is to support the attribute.

'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'open_issues': 0, 'closed_issues': 39, 'state': 'open', 'created_at': '2015-07-08T18:43:46Z', 'updated_at': '2015-12-29T21:41:17Z', 'due_on': None, 'closed_at': None}",5,2015-08-07 20:25:23+00:00,2015-11-10 23:05:00+00:00,2015-11-10 23:05:00+00:00,NONE,,"There are two issues with the flush method that I have found:

1. When I add waypoints and call flush(), the entire mission requires about .25 seconds per waypoint to write in lab conditions. If I attempt to set the vehicle to auto or download the waypoints before all of them are written, the Pixhawk will not receive the full mission and 're-request' the waypoints it missed. When flying, this caused the quad to crash since it got set to auto without home being written properly and came down.

To get around this issue, I call time.sleep(vehicle.commands.count/2) immediately after calling vehicle.flush(). However, if flush() worked properly it would automatically wait until receiving confirmation from the quad that all waypoints had been written before continuing, much like wait_valid() does.

2. After downloading waypoints from the Pixhawk with vehicle.commands.download() and vehicle.commands.wait_valid(), the Pixhawk no longer has a loaded mission, meaning that I can't set it to auto while armed, etc. To reupload the mission I have to actually change a command in the CommandSequence.
I would have figured that simply calling flush() would handle the reupload without me having to change anything, but it doesn't.
These are important issues which need to be solved before lots of people start using Dronekit in real applications. Either fix the flush method add new methods to achieve the required functionality.

,,

This updates the getting started to use Windows DK installer rather than the WinPython installation instructions. Unfortunately the windows installer is started differently, so there are flow on changes to:
- how the connection is set up.
- how to start a script (since you can't start MAVProxy in a specific directory on Windows, I've had to change the instructions to ""first"" suggest the full path.
- Where the examples are (add note that these are available on windows from the installer).
Similar changes needed to be made on the How to Run the examples page.

Last of all, the ""Building DroneKit-Python on Windows"" was updated to include the setup instructions formerly in Getting Started. I also added the additional dependencies reported as missing on Stack overflow.
There might need to be minor updates to this as a result of #267.
I also based this on patch. Hope that is the correct thing to do.

Home location doesn't act in the same way as our .commands array (see above topic for discussion). Instead of patching unexpected behavior, we can extract this ""initial"" command as a separate `Vehicle.home_location` variable.

,,
30,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/251,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/251/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/251/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/251/events,https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/251,97805715,MDU6SXNzdWU5NzgwNTcxNQ==,251,DRONEKIT_PATH variable,{'login': 'djnugent', 'id': 6732731, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjY3MzI3MzE=', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars1.githubusercontent.com/u/6732731?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/djnugent', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/djnugent', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/djnugent/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/djnugent/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/djnugent/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/djnugent/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/djnugent/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/djnugent/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/djnugent/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/djnugent/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/djnugent/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}",[],closed,False,,[],,6,2015-07-28 21:28:30+00:00,2015-10-14 14:06:24+00:00,2015-10-14 14:06:23+00:00,NONE,,"Currently dronekit only supports relative and absolute paths. It would be nice if we could point `api start <file>` to look at a set of directories when running a script. DRONEKIT_PATH would point to your project folders.

This idea was brought up in a recent dronekit session Chris and I had. At a minimum we should specify in the documentation that if that user can't specify the directory in which mavproxy is started(i.e. running SITL), then they must start use an absolute path to call their script.
DRONEKIT_PATH should not be necessary for when we run dronekit without mavproxy. But at a minimum we should document that the user should provide an absolute path when running dronekit scripts.

None}]",closed,False,,[],,4,2015-07-23 04:37:22+00:00,2015-11-07 05:36:20+00:00,2015-11-07 01:39:12+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"If you clear `Vehicle.commands` then you must redownload the mission before trying to add any new  waypoints or the addition will fail. The code below demonstrates this - if you remove the commented out lines then the new waypoint is added, but otherwise it is not.

This feels like a bug. If you've just cleared the commands from the mission then you're expecting it to be empty and ready for re-use. Even if the clearing failed at the autopilot end I would still hope that when I upload my mission it will be doing so assuming a cleared mission list.
from droneapi.lib import VehicleMode, Location, Command
print 'Check we have just 2 items in mission.'

P.S. Note the time.sleep near the end. This is required for the reasons given in  #227. You can remove it and everything after it and still verify this issue by loading the waypoints using mission planner.

'2015-12-29T21:41:17Z', 'due_on': None, 'closed_at': None}",6,2015-07-22 04:35:34+00:00,2015-11-10 23:11:56+00:00,2015-11-10 23:11:56+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"Consider the code below (gist at https://gist.github.com/hamishwillee/9607b3707fb942d59abf#file-gistfile1-txt-L36)
Tests race condition when downloading items
from droneapi.lib import VehicleMode, Location, Command
The code works as is, but if the `time.sleep(2)` is removed then all waypoints are wiped (except the home waypoint).

This shouldn't happen because in theory the flush means that the new waypoint is sent, and this should occur before flush returns - ie before we have a chance to do the new download of the current commands.
I think either we're not doing this properly and the vehicle.command is being wiped by the second call before the flush returns OR the autopilot is confused by our messaging.

,,

We can now break it down into three groups:
- Unit tests, aka mocks, for testing API compliance (""fast tests"")
- Web tests, for the ever-changing DKCLOUD (requires an API key)
- SITL tests, for integration with real examples and docs (""slow tests"")

'updated_at': '2015-07-27T23:43:01Z', 'due_on': None, 'closed_at': '2015-07-27T23:43:01Z'}",7,2015-07-18 04:26:45+00:00,2015-07-27 22:16:15+00:00,2015-07-27 22:16:15+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"Protobuf is required by dronekit-python, but is not always included in a MAVProxy installation. Thus this patch gathers up protobuf into the dronekit-python installer.
MAVProxy is dependant on the mavlink package. Mavlink lists protobuf as ""optional"", so it may or may not exist in the user's environment.
When MAVProxy is compiled into a setup.exe, protobuf may or may not be included due to the above. Thus we can't assume that it's always included in a MAVProxy environment.

16:37:19+00:00,2015-07-27 19:05:48+00:00,2015-07-17 00:19:26+00:00,NONE,,"I'm running an APMcopter SITL with DroneKit/MAVproxy.  When DroneKit is ""flying"" in AUTO mode in the SITL with an 8 waypoint mission, the following function calls returns fine, but fail to actually change the current waypoint.  I've confirmed that the next(value) property setter does get invoked, it just doesn't actually change the current waypoint onboard the copter nor does it change what the next() getter returns (it was waypoint #1 before and waypoint #1 after the below function calls).
If I do a set_mode command after changing the value of next and doing the flush(), the current waypoint will indeed change to #5 as intended.  Welcome any thoughts :)

00:38:42+00:00,2015-08-12 00:12:46+00:00,2015-07-14 09:02:48+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"Right now, this only tests a very trivial property check and code around timing #12. This PR would serve as the basis for forthcoming tests.

The test rig itself is wonky, but it's designed to emulate a single-script test as much as possible. In a first-class DKPY module, we'd be using `nosetests` and these would be straightforward to port over.
You can run it by running `cd tests; python -m sitl`.

'https://api.github.com/users/tcr3dr/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'open_issues': 0, 'closed_issues': 39, 'state': 'open', 'created_at': '2015-07-08T18:43:46Z', 'updated_at': '2015-12-29T21:41:17Z', 'due_on': None, 'closed_at': None}",7,2015-07-09 17:16:58+00:00,2015-10-14 23:47:46+00:00,2015-10-14 14:01:34+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"dronekit-python 1.0 is structured as a MAVProxy module. This had the following implications:
- Allows reuse of MAVProxy's object and state code
- Runs as a component of MAVProxy's threading model
Given the successful first release, we're increasingly running into this friction:

- Naive use of dronekit-python, expecting it to be single-threaded, creates race conditions. (https://github.com/diydrones/dronekit-python/issues/12, https://github.com/diydrones/dronekit-python/issues/74)
- Script lifetime management expects processes, not threads. ([#159](https://github.com/diydrones/dronekit-python/issues/159))
- MAVProxy contains several dependencies (GUI and numerical related) which may not be used by dronekit-python (https://github.com/Dronecode/MAVProxy/issues/159)
There are now strong reasons to consider moving dronekit-python to run as a ""top-level"" library:
- We avoid further complicating MAVProxy's process model by duplicating OS-level functionality.
- We allow reuse of dronekit-python as the ""object layer"" that we expect it to be.
- Mavlink routing becomes simpler, as a dronekit-python script becomes just another Mavlink endpoint.
- We improve automated testing by allowing dronekit-python to be tested in isolation.
Having outlined the reasons, we're looking for discussion on:
- How high-priority this is (what features are blocked by not having this implemented)
- What risks we need to mitigate (duplication of code, etc.)
This is currently slated for the next major release of dronekit-python (v2.0.0).

05:36:23+00:00,2015-07-24 21:22:37+00:00,2015-07-24 21:22:37+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"1. Added vehicle.rangefinder attributed (only the class was documented). Updated class with units information and information about what happens if rangefinder not supported (returns None).

2. Updated the vehicle_state example and example docs to report the rangefinder values. The example docs now link to information on setting up simulated rangefinder. I took the option to change the Vehicle variable name from ""v"" to ""vehicle"" (purely for consistency with other examples) and tidy up the introductory text.

3. Updated the vehicle state guide to list the new attributes and show how they are obtained. I updated the section on using the observer to show how you can cache the value from the callback. I also made this behaviour sound less like a bug (#60).

@djnugent I just tried the fix in #174 against our examples. They crashed because math is not defined in the example script. I don't believe that our examples should ""have"" to import this dependency, which means that you will need to import this in dronekit.
Crash is in the simple_goto.py example (unmodified).
NameError: global name 'math' is not defined
Of course I could be doing something completely wrong ... in which case ""help""!

'2015-11-19T22:00:27Z', 'due_on': None, 'closed_at': None}",18,2015-06-18 23:24:57+00:00,2018-06-11 16:24:23+00:00,2015-11-19 22:00:27+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"At the moment we have attributes and some methods that let us query specific information from the vehicle (home position, location, gps etc). We can send MAVLink messages that ""do"" something - set Yaw, move to position, set servo value, etc.

What we don't have is a public method to get arbitrary information back from the vehicle. So for example I can sent a message to the API with the message ID requesting the camera status or the current value of a particular servo, but I can't then get the response back into my application.
In particular it would be great to be able to query the capabilities of a particular target platform.

This was denied as an option for issue #114 since mavlink is a ""lossy protocol."" I am not aware of the properties which make mavlink ""lossy"", but I feel this method would allow the user to see that the connection is acting ""lossy"" if the COMMAND_ACK message times out.

> Added by HamishW - from Stephen email
1. The installer looks for the MAVProxy directory and installs the contents of the ./droneapi and ./examples directories into there.
2. Then simply use the ""module load droneapi.module.api"" to load it in MAVProxy. (#HW note, it does use the init script too!)
3. The examples can be loaded by the usual ""api start ./examples/folder/script""
4. A minimum of MAVProxy 1.4.20 is required to run DroneAPI
- The script assumes Python is installed in C:\Python27
The script gets the version number from dronekit's setup.py (It assumes there is a line like `# version = ""12344""`)

'2015-11-19T22:00:27Z', 'due_on': None, 'closed_at': None}",11,2015-06-10 20:07:42+00:00,2015-11-10 23:12:09+00:00,2015-11-10 00:33:50+00:00,MEMBER,,"exposes the `system_status` field from the most recently received heartbeat message
handy for checking whether they vehicle is on the ground, flying, in failsafe, etc
| MAV_STATE_UNINIT | Uninitialized system, state is unknown. |
| MAV_STATE_CALIBRATING | System is calibrating and not flight-ready. |
| MAV_STATE_STANDBY | System is grounded and on standby. It can be launched any time. |
| MAV_STATE_ACTIVE | System is active and might be already airborne. Motors are engaged. |
| MAV_STATE_CRITICAL | System is in a non-normal flight mode. It can however still navigate. |
| MAV_STATE_EMERGENCY | System is in a non-normal flight mode. It lost control over parts or over the whole airframe. It is in mayday and going down. |
| MAV_STATE_POWEROFF | System just initialized its power-down sequence, will shut down now. |
@hamishwillee can you update this branch with docs to match this change please?
big thanks to @liamstask for the contribution.

Make it more clear that quick start is explicitly windows only. Don't even mention other operating systems. Or have a quick start for as OS's.
2. Step 5 does not work with native windows because windows does not have a SSH client installed
Solution: Install putty, Connect to 127.0.0.1:2222, username: vagrant, password: vagrant
3. Step 7 in the quick start instructs the user to configure mavproxy using ""echo... >> some file""
However, prior to step 7, there is no mention of mavproxy and how to install it.
Personal note: Quick start seems like a non informative version of the guide. I would prefer to just have guides

'default': False, 'description': None}]",closed,False,,[],,11,2015-06-04 17:54:27+00:00,2015-07-27 19:05:48+00:00,2015-06-11 22:16:02+00:00,NONE,,"The docs for droniekit-python windows should specify that the user run the winpython installer as an admin and that they run command-prompt as an admin. If the user is not admin they will get stuck very quickly.

Also a note about the winpython install location: If you open the installer from your downloads folder then it defaults to install in the downloads folder unless the user specifies another location. We should specify that the user install in the programs(x86) folder and then tell them to navigate there to access the winpython control panel.

splits ""Contributing"" out into its own section and splits up the original docs appropriately. It adds  instructions on how to set up dev environment using Linux/Vagrant.  This is appropriate because we are now getting more interest and contributions, and we need to make it easier for people to contribute.
All the instructions are significantly updated:

- I reduced Daniel's Linux instructions to reference the existing wiki document (which gets updated by the ArduPilot team). This also fixes some limitations with the original doc like the fact that it is Copter-specific.
- I added a very brief style-guide to the documentation section.
I think this is good, but I will need to re-read it tomorrow. At the moment I am too close to the text and would not see defects.

The update does it the right way. I updated the example documentation along with this.

In addition, I created a guide topic for taking off (copter only) and added apireference for the takeoff function (note, this is just in ""text"" and I still think we need to expose the method in the API properly).

discarded (probably by DroneKit). The following code shows how to create  a number of missions, starting with takeoff.
pitch=45 #take off pitch. Need to check if degrees or radians, and what is a reasonable valued.
The output below shows the missions as sent, and the missions that are then re-retrieved from the vehicle. The first mission item is simply discarded (the first mission item is now the home)
Got MAVLink msg: MISSION_ACK {target_system : 255, target_component : 0, type : 1}

Sent waypoint 0 : MISSION_ITEM {target_system : 1, target_component : 0, seq : 0, frame : 3, command : 22, current : 0, autocontinue : 0, param1 : 45, param2 : 0, param3 : 0, param4 : 0, x : 0, y : 0, z : 100}

Sent waypoint 1 : MISSION_ITEM {target_system : 1, target_component : 0, seq : 1, frame : 3, command : 16, current : 0, autocontinue : 0, param1 : 0, param2 : 0, param3 : 0, param4 : 0, x : -35.363768, y : 149.154275, z : 110}

Sent waypoint 2 : MISSION_ITEM {target_system : 1, target_component : 0, seq : 2, frame : 3, command : 16, current : 0, autocontinue : 0, param1 : 0, param2 : 0, param3 : 0, param4 : 0, x : -35.3666207, y : 149.16628, z : 120}

Sent waypoint 3 : MISSION_ITEM {target_system : 1, target_component : 0, seq : 3, frame : 3, command : 17, current : 0, autocontinue : 0, param1 : 0, param2 : 0, param3 : 0, param4 : 0, x : -35.363769, y : 149.154276, z : 130}
Got MAVLink msg: MISSION_ACK {target_system : 255, target_component : 0, type : 0}
Requesting 4 waypoints t=Wed May 20 17:58:44 2015 now=Wed May 20 17:58:44 2015

Command MISSION_ITEM {target_system : 255, target_component : 0, seq : 0, frame : 0, command : 16, current : 0, autocontinue : 1, param1 : 0.0, param2 : 0.0, param3 : 0.0, param4 : 0.0, x : -35.3632621765, y : 149.165237427, z : 584.099975586}

Command MISSION_ITEM {target_system : 255, target_component : 0, seq : 1, frame : 3, command : 16, current : 0, autocontinue : 1, param1 : 0.0, param2 : 0.0, param3 : 0.0, param4 : 0.0, x : -35.3637695312, y : 149.154281616, z : 110.0}

Command MISSION_ITEM {target_system : 255, target_component : 0, seq : 2, frame : 3, command : 16, current : 0, autocontinue : 1, param1 : 0.0, param2 : 0.0, param3 : 0.0, param4 : 0.0, x : -35.3666191101, y : 149.166275024, z : 120.0}

Command MISSION_ITEM {target_system : 255, target_component : 0, seq : 3, frame : 3, command : 17, current : 0, autocontinue : 1, param1 : 0.0, param2 : 0.0, param3 : 1.0, param4 : 0.0, x : -35.3637695312, y : 149.154281616, z : 130.0}

This is a serious bug! I suspect that someone thought that since copter ignores the takeoff command in AUTO it could be removed, but testing shows that it removes any command irrespective of type. Also Plane doesn't ignore the command.
In the short term someone could work around this by adding the takeoff command twice.

The interesting text is:

> The flight mode determines the behaviour of the vehicle, and what commands it can obey. DroneKit apps should typically use the AUTO mode for waypoint missions and GUIDED mode otherwise. Care should be taken when using manual modes as these may require remote control input from the user (RETURN_TO_LAUNCH is generally safe!)
This links to the state/parameters guide introduced in #124 (not yet in master), but will build and read OK even if that commit is not yet present.

installation on Intel Edison,  it is failing during the pip install phase because it is not finding ""../src/google/protobuf/unittest.proto""
This causes a 'Failed to load module: No module named google.protobuf.internal' error when trying to load the droneapi module in mavproxy.
The error is caused by ['protobuf >= 2.5.0' ],which pulls the pip protobuf and still has line 73 as:
The official git has updated setup.py to include:
# Unittest protos are only needed for development.
This problem can be fixed by editing the protobuf/setup.py file and re-running pip install.

Obviously the uninstall / install has messed it up somehow but can't see where. The output at the bottom shows there is multiple instances of the api.py file. Maybe the path to the correct location is missing?
Any ideas how to fix this?

[VehicleMode](http://python.dronekit.io/automodule.html#droneapi.lib.VehicleMode) reference to _recommend_ AUTO and GUIDED modes.

At the moment we don't really comment on this other than to point to the supported modes. In practice though you really shouldn't be using dronekit within a manual mode (which may _require_ a transmitter) unless you know what you're doing. These modes are supported on all platforms and are known to be safe.

The copter has no response when it receives the command. However, this example can work very well in simulator. This is really confused me.
In 'https://github.com/rmackay9/ardupilot-balloon-finder' project, the Copter can response to command â€˜send_nav_velocity(velocity_x, velocity_y, velocity_z)â€™.
Is something wrong with my hardware or software settings?  I really need help....

23:21:30+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"`Vehicle.add_attribute_observer` will add an observer as many times as it is called, and  `Vehicle.remove_attribute_observer` will remove as many instances of the observer as times it is called.

IMO you might want to assign multiple observers to the same attribute, but I would expect them to be different. You might in theory want to also apply the same observer to multiple attributes. However a callback should really only be added once as an observer for an attribute, however many times it is called to be added.

The code below shows that if add_attribute_observer is called 4 times to add an observer, and then removed once, the callback is called 3 times. It should be called once, however many times it is added.
# Now change the vehicle into STABILIZE mode

None}]",closed,False,,[],,0,2015-05-13 06:08:18+00:00,2015-07-27 19:05:48+00:00,2015-05-28 17:07:44+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"The [small_demo.py](https://github.com/diydrones/dronekit-python/blob/master/example/small_demo/small_demo.py) example contains information about getting and setting vehicle state and parameters (including the rc_overrides). This should be renamed to explain what the content is actually about. I am proposing ""vehicle_state.py"" because the name ""state"" can be used to imply this is about both the dynamic attributes (position, speed etc) and also the parameters (settings - including RC overrides).
The file should have the following updates:

- Enable the mode callback which is currently disabled. Add an ""armed"" callback. No need to implement other callbacks because we can't change them in this ""static"" example. Show how to remove both of these.
- Enable a set_mavlink_callback() (currently disabled). Show how to disable this.
- Show all the attributes being fetched (currently does most, but add mount and any other missing attributes)
- Show how to set parameters (currently commented out). Add links to other parameters? Show what happens if unsupported parameter used?
- Remove the ""Test custom commands"" commented out material
- Add clear section markers/comments to each section.
Add a document about this example in the docset.
Add a guide document about setting parameters etc.

It also removes documentation about parameter change notification, which is not supported.
It addresses #101, #100, #103,#89, #99 (see those posts for more information).
I also split down a number of the longer lines to make them a little shorter (cosmetic/layout). This was to improve the readability of the source in github.

02:20:11+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"Vehicle.waypoint_home was in the original documentation, but is not present in the implementation (MPVehicle). According to @geeksville (#100)
> this was probably inadvertently lost when full command access was added (.. vehicle.commands[0] is guaranteed to be home). It would be easy to add it back.
Action is to add an implementation for getting this value. Also to consider adding a setter - that makes sense to me because then you could easily change the home position outside of missions.

07:20:20+00:00,2015-06-01 00:41:30+00:00,2015-06-01 00:41:30+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"The API should expose battery/power information.

This should ideally include raw numbers like ""available charge"" and ""voltage"", ""current"", ""remaining power"", ""consumed power"". If possible, good to have an estimated flight time at current consumption.
It is possible for a vehicle to have multiple batteries, and the API should be capable of exposing the information for at least 2.

In addition, we need guide documentation on these. The documentation should cover that there are a number of ways to send messages. For example COMMAND LONG is a basic message format that can be used to send any seven parameter command. So you could use:
However you could also send this command using its own method like below. The benefit being that you don't have to think about command ids, sequence numbers etc.:

01:25:47+00:00,2015-05-07 02:47:35+00:00,2015-05-07 01:40:48+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"The API Reference on Python IO does not reflect the current API.

The documentation is auto-generated from [**init**.py](https://github.com/diydrones/dronekit-python/blob/master/droneapi/lib/__init__.py). If you look at this source you can see that this differs quite a lot from [what is published](http://python.dronekit.io/automodule.html). When I build this locally the built reference matches the file ([example here on my dropbox](https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/3067678/share2/dronekit-python/html/automodule.html) ).
This does not appear to be a caching issue on the page or with the ""whole build"" (since the rest of the docs on python.dronekit.io are correct and reflect changes from the latest pull request).
@mrpollo I think this is something very wrong with Sphinx build. Possibly it has failed to build the automodule? In any case, this is important.

- There is some duplication of commands for installing droneapi (ie done as a dependency and at the end)
- The instructions to install Mavproxy aren't really needed as this is done automatically as it is a Droneapi dependency in pip
- The instructions stop after installation. A get started should really go through to running an example.

It should not be used to directly drive a vehicle, except as a last resort. Instead the appropriate mavlink commands should be used.
The following examples set the channel_override in  a way that we would not recommend:
- strip this from small_demo and simple_goto, and create a small independent demo that shows just this behaviour.
- add a warning in the new example's code and docs about this use case
- replace the throttle setting in the simple_goto with a more appropriate command for setting the throttle.

02:19:45+00:00,2015-05-13 03:27:25+00:00,2015-05-13 03:27:25+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"There is no implementation for battery_0_soc and battery_0_volt. Please provide implementation and information about what parameters these map to on ardupilot (basically I need to know their ""meaning"" and possible values and units - so for example ""Remaining capacity of the first battery in X units""

It is possible for a UAV to have multiple batteries, and two are specified in the [parameters](http://copter.ardupilot.com/wiki/configuration/arducopter-parameters/#batt__parameters). This implies that there should actually be multiple values for these, or a way to index them.

I verified the lack of these parameters by inspection and testing. To test, I added the following lines to [small_demo.py](https://github.com/diydrones/dronekit-python/blob/master/example/small_demo/small_demo.py#L32):
Exception in APIThread-2: 'MPVehicle' object has no attribute 'battery_0_soc'

01:26:16+00:00,2015-07-27 19:05:47+00:00,2015-05-06 03:53:39+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"The API contains a number of APIs that are not fully implemented, and may never be. We do not intend people to use them at the current time. They are however publically visible and currently documented.
IN addition there are APIs that are internal in that we don't expect people to call them (please confirm)
- vehicle.delete - I think this is meaningless for a ""local"" vehicle? If not, what would it mean?
@mrpollo , is that a good set of items to hide/remove?
Obviously it is best that these are either fully implemented and so are usuable or are removed from the public API. In the meantime I propose:
- Hide in the documented API. We can do this by adding this flag to the rst automodule directive
:exclude-members: Mission, get_mission, ConnectionInfo, web_connect, AuthInfo, notify_observers
- Remove all other mention of them in the documentation
- Include status warnings (""not supported"") in the source so that people reading the source can see these are not public and are intentionally not documented.
Note: This does not apply to ""deprecated"" APIs. APIs that might have been used by developers in the past need to be tagged as deprecated.

78,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/64,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/64/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/64/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/64/events,https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/64,69036175,MDU6SXNzdWU2OTAzNjE3NQ==,64,API modifications to fix missing/confusing reference,{'login': 'hamishwillee', 'id': 5368500, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjUzNjg1MDA=', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars2.githubusercontent.com/u/5368500?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/hamishwillee', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}","[{'id': 88720671, 'node_id': 'MDU6TGFiZWw4ODcyMDY3MQ==', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/labels/bug', 'name': 'bug', 'color': 'fc2929', 'default': True, 'description': None}]",closed,False,,[],,3,2015-04-17 00:26:40+00:00,2015-05-06 04:49:10+00:00,2015-05-06 04:49:10+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"The current API Reference is built from droneapi.lib module by Sphinx, which pulls it from comments in _/droneapi/module/api.py_ and _droneapi/lib/**init**.py_. I've done a bit of a comparison of what is in the files and what is documented and have some suggestions:

1. Documentation in **init** refers to objects as ""base class"" and has comments like ""implemented in subclass"".  This is useful for a developer, but confusing for a user. If the base class is an interface, then it should just say what the interface does.
> HW I have updated these cases in the source so they are marked as ""Internal notes""
2. Attributes of Vehicle are documented in a table in the interface class. It would be better if these were part of the public ""imported"" API.
> HW I have updated these cases in the source using py:attribute markup. However it would be better if these were ""properly"" in the public API.
1. CommandSequence.takeoff is missing in public API/documentation - created separate defect #70
2. CommandSequence.next setter is not appearing in public API - #83 83
3. Order source by preferred order of display to improve readability #84

98,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/43,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/43/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/43/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/43/events,https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/43,66071517,MDU6SXNzdWU2NjA3MTUxNw==,43,Provide information and vagrant file on how to contribute to docs?,"{'login': 'hamishwillee', 'id': 5368500, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjUzNjg1MDA=', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars2.githubusercontent.com/u/5368500?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/hamishwillee', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}","[{'id': 88720673, 'node_id': 'MDU6TGFiZWw4ODcyMDY3Mw==', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/labels/enhancement', 'name': 'enhancement', 'color': '84b6eb', 'default': True, 'description': None}]",closed,False,,[],,3,2015-04-03 04:19:17+00:00,2015-07-27 19:05:47+00:00,2015-04-07 22:49:52+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"We should make it easier for people to get started with contributing to the documents. The good news is that _sphinx_3dr_theme_ can now be updated from pip, so it is now possible to set up sphinx and build the source without having to modify any files (previously you needed to modify the conf file in order to replace the theme).
I've written a vagrant script that does this. The proposal is to put this in /docs/ alongside the .rst files. The (windows) workflow would be:
1. Create a fork of this project
3. Navigate to your docs folder and run ""vagrant up"". This will bring up the VM, add sphinx and the theme, pull the latest code git, then build (call ""make html"").
4. Users can then modify the files in their windows file system/notepadd++ and cause a new build by running: `vagrant ssh  -c ""cd /vagrant && make html""`
5. They can commit the changes and do other git activities through windows. (or through the VM).
Is this approach desirable? Is the location of the vagrantfile in docs OK? (I think it is, but just checking).
In addition, I propose to update README.md to add information about how to contribute (specifically to the docs, but more generally it would be useful to cover how people can join the project?).
I would do this by adding a new heading ""Contributing"" near the end with a link ""Contributing to the Documentation"". That doc would explain how to use the vagrant file etc.

The text in the first paragraph might be improved:

> DroneKit-Python provides interfaces for creating  applications that run on an onboard Linux computer communicating directly to the autopilot of 3DR-powered vehicles or applications that run on a personal computer communicating with vehicles over a wireless connection.
It does talk about the fact that the API can be used on Linux computer and on ground stations (good). The problems are that it:
- uses term ""onboard Linux computer"" where we use ""Companion Computer"" elsewhere.
- does not specify the ground station OS other than saying ""personal computer""
- doesn't cover the benefits of a companion computer (desirable)
- specifies ""autopilot on a 3DR-powered vehicle - and this is suppose to be general.
- The different communication methods for ground station vs companion computer is interesting but not quite as important.

6,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/35,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/35/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/35/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/35/events,https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/35,65383772,MDU6SXNzdWU2NTM4Mzc3Mg==,35,DOC: Getting Started - content and structural issues,{'login': 'hamishwillee', 'id': 5368500, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjUzNjg1MDA=', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars2.githubusercontent.com/u/5368500?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/hamishwillee', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/hamishwillee/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}",[],closed,False,,[],,5,2015-03-31 07:13:20+00:00,2015-07-27 19:05:47+00:00,2015-05-06 04:59:08+00:00,CONTRIBUTOR,,"http://python.dronekit.io/getting_started.html

1. The companion computer information is not sufficiently visible because it is right at the end of a long document. It is also discussed in the body of the doc before it is mentioned. The section could be moved to the top (before SITL) or it more likely we could start with an introductory sentence explaining that we cover both setting up in a simulated environment and on a companion computer, with a link down.

1. The [Companion computer link](http://dev.ardupilot.com/wiki/companion-computers/) is not very helpful for explaining what you do next. It refers to different hardware and to the DroneAPI rather than DroneKit. As a reader I don't think it will be clear that they are the same thing, and what you do next. I think we need to use DroneKit terminology to make that link clear. It would also help possibly to have this/these docs written so that it is obvious which bit of the task is ""installing dronekit"".
2. SITL and Installing DroneKit section feels a bit complicated:
- Set up a simulated vehicle | Dependencies - is just wrong. Should be renamed to ""Setting up in a Virtual Machine"" and should be after the following ""Setting up on Linux"" topic.
- Ideally we should note that there are timing issues in a VM but that it is still great for basic app testing.
- Link to the VAGRANT setup as it is much better - provided it can do the job (?)
- No need to talk about VirtualBox or whatever here as a dependency, that gets covered in the linked docs.

- [Installing DroneKit](http://python.dronekit.io/getting_started.html#installing-dronekit) looks a bit odd because the ""optional"" dependencies are at the same level as thinks like setting up MAVLink.

Also we talk about installing dronekit on windows and MAC, and I find this confusing because we have SITL running on the VM. We need to make it clear where dronekit runs and how it fits with SITL simulation/MAVLINK.

Consider 2 options: a) putting the ""dependencies"" under a common heading. OR b) have an end to end topic ""Setting up DroneKit on Linux"" and then have separate sections covering setting up on Windows/Mac. These can just say ""it's the same, but instead you need to do X, Y, Z""

29,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/11,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/11/labels{/name},https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/11/comments,https://api.github.com/repos/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/11/events,https://github.com/dronekit/dronekit-python/issues/11,43573966,MDU6SXNzdWU0MzU3Mzk2Ng==,11,How to store a set of waypoints for AUTO mode,{'login': 'stephen-t-dodds', 'id': 8052989, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjgwNTI5ODk=', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars3.githubusercontent.com/u/8052989?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/stephen-t-dodds', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/stephen-t-dodds', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/stephen-t-dodds/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/stephen-t-dodds/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/stephen-t-dodds/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/stephen-t-dodds/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/stephen-t-dodds/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/stephen-t-dodds/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/stephen-t-dodds/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/stephen-t-dodds/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/stephen-t-dodds/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}",[],closed,False,,[],,3,2014-09-23 00:13:44+00:00,2015-05-06 04:41:56+00:00,2015-05-06 04:41:56+00:00,NONE,,"Hi,
Mavlink allows you to set a group of waypoints to be executed by AUTO mode by using the ""set waypointfile.txt"" command.

Have you created a function that emulates the ""set"" command so that waypoints can be saved to the drone? I looked extensively in your documentation and I have not found anything that resembles this command.
I did notice that in small_demo.py you have access to the waypoints that are already set using cmds[x] structure:
However, you cannot save to the cmds[x] structure, you have only given access to printing the contents (at least as far as my experimentation has shown me).

If there is not such a function in droneapi yet, would you please make one? I do not mind making the text file if you could make some sort of function that ""sets"" the text file as the waypoints. However, It would be even more nice if you had a way to just ""set"" waypoints into the AUTO mode list using some sort of structure.

Our team was able to run the follow_me.py example without debugging errors in two different ways. The first way we ran it, was exactly as the follow_me.py was written, and the second way was hardcoding one GPS coordinate in the Location function. However, in both cases we received the proper debugging output but the motors did not move.

The first way we ran it, was exactly as the follow_me.py was written. Our GPS USB dongle was providing GPS coordinates every two seconds, those coordinates were displayed, and the output showed â€œGot MAVLink msg: MISSION_ACK... etc.
The second way we ran it was with all the gpsd functions commented out and by hard-coding one GPS coordinate in the Location function.
After educating ourselves on your API, we believe that we have narrowed down the problem to being the goto function does not end up forcing the drone to move the motors.
Do you have any thoughts on why this could be happening.

We speculate that the problem may be that the drone is going into Guided mode. We believe that this is your intent. However, from our understanding, the drone will only go to locations autonomously in AUTO mode and only after the waypoints are saved and an rc command starts the motors.
Again, we do not fully understand what is wrong and why the command itself seems to be received by the APM, but the motors are not moving.
Again, we are able to get small_demo.py to move the motors properly, so we know it is not a problem with our wiring or our connection between the APM and our Raspberry Pi.
I've tried a test with (1) APM <> Raspbian.
--I am able to run 'module load droneapi.module.api'
--When I run 'api start small_demo.py' it seems to work (get 'ARMED' commands and other) but I get the following error message. Any ideas what might be causing the error?

email:
Is there a way to call  DroneAPI without the interactive MavProxy ?
I have MavProxy running in the background and the droneapi.module loaded:
If I execute small_demo.py outside of interactive MavProxy it fails on this line:
I assume that the function would find my local running copy but I guess that is a wrong assumption?
Of course it runs fine inside the interactive MavProxy but only after it completes loading â€¦.. so I canâ€™t use the â€œapi startâ€ as a parameter.

> Lastly, I was just wondering if you were going to implement the ""set_mavlink_callback"" method? I am not sure exactly why but my boss says that is something that he is looking for. I wish I had more information for you but all I know is that he says it is necessary for the project.

Yes, oops - I hadn't noticed that we had missed that one.  Yes - I'll add that tomorrow and push out a new release.  Also it is worth noting that all of the attributes on vehicle, waypoints, parameters etc... support callbacks which might be a better way to go.  (see documentation for add_attribute_observer).  What mavlink packets were you needing to watch for?  I just want to make sure we didn't miss anything that really should be in the common (web enabled) interface instead.
Thanks for you time and all of the amazing effort you have put in on this project!

2 - the fact that in randy's code there is 4 different places where he has to ""download the vehicle waypoints if we don't have them already"" , presumably, ""just to be sure""...?

3 - the send_nav_velocity() and condition_yaw() functions which would be convenient helper function/s in the drone.api directly. ... and probably the advance_current_cmd() function too...    none of them are specific to the balloon thing in any way, and are clearly good-looking helper-apps to simplify the api or wrapper-up some common messages into something more human.  :-)

4 - the move_to_balloon() , which should really be called move_to_position(), as that's what it does ( it contrains speed, and determines vector/s, and then calls send_nav_velocity() for the mavlink itself....
none of this is ""balloon"" code, it's really just convenience wrappers around the api....
